column3: number theory" "This is an interactive problem.Misha likes to play cooperative games with incomplete information. Today he suggested ten his friends to play a cooperative game ""Lake"".Misha has already come up with a field for the upcoming game. The field for this game is a directed graph consisting of two parts. The first part is a road along the coast of the lake which is a cycle of c vertices. The second part is a path from home to the lake which is a chain of t vertices
column4: and there is an edge from the last vertex of this chain to the vertex of the road along the coast which has the most beautiful view of the lake
column5: also known as the finish vertex. Misha decided to keep the field secret
column6: so nobody knows neither t nor c.  Note that each vertex of the field has exactly one outgoing edge and all the vertices except the home vertex and the finish vertex have exactly one ingoing edge. The home vertex has no incoming edges
column7: the finish vertex has two incoming edges.At the beginning of the game pieces of all the ten players
column8: indexed with consecutive integers from 0 to 9
column9: are at the home vertex. After that on each turn some of the players can ask Misha to simultaneously move their pieces along the corresponding edges. Misha will not answer more than q such queries. After each move Misha will tell players whose pieces are at the same vertices and whose pieces are at different vertices.The goal of the game is to move all the pieces to the finish vertex. Misha\'s friends have no idea how to win in such a game without knowledge of c
column10: t and q
column11: but luckily they are your friends. Help them: coordinate their actions to win the game. Misha has drawn such a field that 1\xe2\x89\xa4t
column12: c

column3: implementation "In the country N
column4: there are n cities connected by m one-way roads. Although this country seems unremarkable
column5: there are two interesting facts about it. At first
column6: a week lasts d days here. At second
column7: there is exactly one museum in each city of the country N.Travel agency ""Open museums"" is developing a new program for tourists interested in museums. Agency\'s employees know which days each of the museums is open. The tour should start in the capitalÂ \xe2\x80\x94 the city number 1
column8: and the first day of the tour must be on the first day of a week. Each day a tourist will be in some city
column9: watching the exposition in its museum (in case museum is open today)
column10: and by the end of the day
column11: the tour either ends or the tourist goes into another city connected by a road with the current one. The road system of N is designed in such a way that traveling by a road always takes one night and also all the roads are one-way. It\'s allowed to visit a city multiple times during the trip.You should develop such route for the trip that the number of distinct museums
column12: possible to visit during it
column13: is maximum." 2500

column3: strings "The new camp by widely-known over the country Spring Programming Camp is going to start soon. Hence
column4: all the team of friendly curators and teachers started composing the camp\'s schedule. After some continuous discussion
column5: they came up with a schedule s
column6: which can be represented as a binary string
column7: in which the i-th symbol is \'1\' if students will write the contest in the i-th day and \'0\' if they will have a day off.At the last moment Gleb said that the camp will be the most productive if it runs with the schedule t (which can be described in the same format as schedule s). Since the number of days in the current may be different from number of days in schedule t
column8: Gleb required that the camp\'s schedule must be altered so that the number of occurrences of t in it as a substring is maximum possible. At the same time
column9: the number of contest days and days off shouldn\'t change
column10: only their order may change.Could you rearrange the schedule in the best possible way?" 1600

column2: sortings "Dora loves adventures quite a lot. During some journey she encountered an amazing city
column3: which is formed by n streets along the Eastern direction and m streets across the Southern direction. Naturally
column4: this city has nm intersections. At any intersection of i-th Eastern street and j-th Southern street there is a monumental skyscraper. Dora instantly became curious and decided to explore the heights of the city buildings.When Dora passes through the intersection of the i-th Eastern and j-th Southern street she examines those two streets. After Dora learns the heights of all the skyscrapers on those two streets she wonders: how one should reassign heights to the skyscrapers on those two streets
column5: so that the maximum height would be as small as possible and the result of comparing the heights of any two skyscrapers on one street wouldn\'t change.Formally
column6: on every of nm intersections Dora solves an independent problem. She sees n+m\xe2\x88\x921 skyscrapers and for each of them she knows its real height. Moreover
column7: any two heights can be compared to get a result ""greater""
column8: ""smaller"" or ""equal"". Now Dora wants to select some integer x and assign every skyscraper a height from 1 to x. When assigning heights
column9: Dora wants to preserve the relative order of the skyscrapers in both streets. That is
column10: the result of any comparison of heights of two skyscrapers in the current Eastern street shouldn\'t change and the result of any comparison of heights of two skyscrapers in current Southern street shouldn\'t change as well. Note that skyscrapers located on the Southern street are not compared with skyscrapers located on the Eastern street only. However
column11: the skyscraper located at the streets intersection can be compared with both Southern and Eastern skyscrapers. For every intersection Dora wants to independently calculate the minimum possible x.For example
column12: if the intersection and the two streets corresponding to it look as follows:  Then it is optimal to replace the heights of the skyscrapers as follows (note that all comparisons ""less""
column13: ""equal""
column14: ""greater"" inside the Eastern street and inside the Southern street are preserved)  The largest used number is 5
column15: hence the answer for this intersection would be 5.Help Dora to compute the answers for each intersection." 1600

column4: by the way

column3: Nastya decided to play computer games. Passing levels one by one
column4: Nastya eventually faced a problem. Her mission is to leave a room
column5: where a lot of monsters live
column6: as quickly as possible.There are n manholes in the room which are situated on one line
column7: but
column8: unfortunately
column9: all the manholes are closed
column10: and there is one stone on every manhole. There is exactly one coin under every manhole
column11: and to win the game Nastya should pick all the coins. Initially Nastya stands near the k-th manhole from the left. She is thinking what to do.In one turn
column12: Nastya can do one of the following:   if there is at least one stone on the manhole Nastya stands near
column13: throw exactly one stone from it onto any other manhole (yes
column14: Nastya is strong).  go to a neighboring manhole;  if there are no stones on the manhole Nastya stays near
column15: she can open it and pick the coin from it. After it she must close the manhole immediately (it doesn\'t require additional moves).   The figure shows the intermediate state of the game. At the current position Nastya can throw the stone to any other manhole or move left or right to the neighboring manholes. If she were near the leftmost manhole
column16: she could open it (since there are no stones on it). Nastya can leave the room when she picks all the coins. Monsters are everywhere
column17: so you need to compute the minimum number of moves Nastya has to make to pick all the coins.Note one time more that Nastya can open a manhole only when there are no stones onto it." 1000

column3: two pointers" "You are a coach at your local university. There are n students under your supervision
column4: the programming skill of the i-th student is ai.You have to form k teams for yet another new programming competition. As you know
column5: the more students are involved in competition the more probable the victory of your university is! So you have to form no more than k (and at least one) non-empty teams so that the total number of students in them is maximized. But you also know that each team should be balanced. It means that the programming skill of each pair of students in each team should differ by no more than 5. Teams are independent from one another (it means that the difference between programming skills of two students from two different teams does not matter).It is possible that some students not be included in any team at all.Your task is to report the maximum possible total number of students in no more than k (and at least one) non-empty balanced teams.If you are Python programmer
column6: consider using PyPy instead of Python when you submit your code." 1800

column2: number theory" "International Women\'s Day is coming soon! Polycarp is preparing for the holiday.There are n candy boxes in the shop for sale. The i-th box contains di candies.Polycarp wants to prepare the maximum number of gifts for k girls. Each gift will consist of exactly two boxes. The girls should be able to share each gift equally

column5: each box can be a part of no more than one gift. Polycarp cannot use boxes ""partially"" or redistribute candies between them." 1200

column2: where x%y is x modulo y). It is also guaranteed that the entire contest is held during a single day. And finally it is guaranteed that the contest lasts at least two minutes.Polycarp wants to know the time of the midpoint of the contest. For example
column3: if the contest lasts from 10:00 to 11:00 then the answer is 10:30
column4: if the contest lasts from 11:10 to 11:12 then the answer is 11:11." 1000

column2: greedy" "Berland SU holds yet another training contest for its students today. n students came
column3: each of them brought his laptop. However
column4: it turned out that everyone has forgot their chargers!Let students be numbered from 1 to n. Laptop of the i-th student has charge ai at the beginning of the contest and it uses bi of charge per minute (i.e. if the laptop has c charge at the beginning of some minute
column5: it becomes c\xe2\x88\x92bi charge at the beginning of the next minute). The whole contest lasts for k minutes.Polycarp (the coach of Berland SU) decided to buy a single charger so that all the students would be able to successfully finish the contest. He buys the charger at the same moment the contest starts.Polycarp can choose to buy the charger with any non-negative (zero or positive) integer power output. The power output is chosen before the purchase
column6: it can\'t be changed afterwards. Let the chosen power output be x. At the beginning of each minute (from the minute contest starts to the last minute of the contest) he can plug the charger into any of the student\'s laptops and use it for some integer number of minutes. If the laptop is using bi charge per minute then it will become bi\xe2\x88\x92x per minute while the charger is plugged in. Negative power usage rate means that the laptop\'s charge is increasing. The charge of any laptop isn\'t limited
column7: it can become infinitely large. The charger can be plugged in no more than one laptop at the same time.The student successfully finishes the contest if the charge of his laptop never is below zero at the beginning of some minute (from the minute contest starts to the last minute of the contest
column8: zero charge is allowed). The charge of the laptop of the minute the contest ends doesn\'t matter.Help Polycarp to determine the minimal possible power output the charger should have so that all the students are able to successfully finish the contest. Also report if no such charger exists." 2300

column7: you want to know what will be the minimum total amount of money you have to pay if you use one of the coupons optimally." 900

column2: implementation "A string is called bracket sequence if it does not contain any characters other than ""("" and "")"". A bracket sequence is called regular if it it is possible to obtain correct arithmetic expression by inserting characters ""+"" and ""1"" into this sequence. For example
column4: ""(())"" and ""()()"" are regular bracket sequences; ""))"" and "")(("" are bracket sequences (but not regular ones)
column5: and ""(a)"" and ""(1)+(1)"" are not bracket sequences at all.You have a number of strings; each string is a bracket sequence of length 2. So
column6: overall you have cnt1 strings ""((""
column7: cnt2 strings ""()""
column8: cnt3 strings "")("" and cnt4 strings ""))"". You want to write all these strings in some order
column9: one after another; after that
column10: you will get a long bracket sequence of length 2(cnt1+cnt2+cnt3+cnt4). You wonder: is it possible to choose some order of the strings you have such that you will get a regular bracket sequence? Note that you may not remove any characters or strings
column11: and you may not add anything either." 1100

column3: two pointers" "Semyon participates in the most prestigious competition of the world ocean for the title of the most dangerous shark. During this competition sharks compete in different subjects: speed swimming
column4: masking
column5: map navigation and many others. Now Semyon is taking part in \xc2\xabdestruction\xc2\xbb contest.During it
column6: m dominoes are placed in front of the shark. All dominoes are on the same line
column7: but the height of the dominoes may vary. The distance between adjacent dominoes is 1. Moreover
column8: each Domino has its own cost value
column9: expressed as an integer. The goal is to drop all the dominoes. To do this
column10: the shark can push any domino to the left or to the right
column11: and it will begin falling in this direction. If during the fall the domino touches other dominoes
column12: they will also start falling in the same direction in which the original domino is falling
column13: thus beginning a chain reaction
column14: as a result of which many dominoes can fall. A falling domino touches another one
column15: if and only if the distance between them was strictly less than the height of the falling domino
column16: the dominoes do not necessarily have to be adjacent.Of course
column17: any shark can easily drop all the dominoes in this way
column18: so the goal is not to drop all the dominoes
column19: but do it with a minimum cost. The cost of the destruction is the sum of the costs of dominoes that the shark needs to push to make all the dominoes fall.Simon has already won in the previous subjects
column20: but is not smart enough to win in this one. Help Semyon and determine the minimum total cost of the dominoes he will have to push to make all the dominoes fall." 2700

column15: having all kittens from two original cells. Since Asya has never putted partitions back

column20: however she doesn\'t remember how she placed kittens in the cage in the beginning. Please help her and find any possible initial arrangement of the kittens into n cells." 1700

column3: strings "Roman and Denis are on the trip to the programming competition. Since the trip was long
column4: they soon got bored
column5: and hence decided to came up with something. Roman invented a pizza\'s recipe
column6: while Denis invented a string multiplication. According to Denis
column7: the result of multiplication (product) of strings s of length m and t is a string t+s1+t+s2+\xe2\x80\xa6+t+sm+t
column8: where si denotes the i-th symbol of the string s
column9: and ""+"" denotes string concatenation. For example
column10: the product of strings ""abc"" and ""de"" is a string ""deadebdecde""
column11: while the product of the strings ""ab"" and ""z"" is a string ""zazbz"". Note
column12: that unlike the numbers multiplication
column13: the product of strings s and t is not necessarily equal to product of t and s.Roman was jealous of Denis
column14: since he invented such a cool operation
column15: and hence decided to invent something string-related too. Since Roman is beauty-lover
column16: he decided to define the beauty of the string as the length of the longest substring
column17: consisting of only one letter. For example
column18: the beauty of the string ""xayyaaabca"" is equal to 3
column19: since there is a substring ""aaa""
column20: while the beauty of the string ""qwerqwer"" is equal to 1
column21: since all neighboring symbols in it are different.In order to entertain Roman
column22: Denis wrote down n strings p1
column23: p2
column24: p3
column25: \xe2\x80\xa6
column26: pn on the paper and asked him to calculate the beauty of the string (\xe2\x80\xa6(((p1\xe2\x8b\x85p2)\xe2\x8b\x85p3)\xe2\x8b\x85\xe2\x80\xa6)\xe2\x8b\x85pn
column27: where s\xe2\x8b\x85t denotes a multiplication of strings s and t. Roman hasn\'t fully realized how Denis\'s multiplication works
column28: so he asked you for a help. Denis knows
column29: that Roman is very impressionable
column30: he guarantees
column31: that the beauty of the resulting string is at most 109." 2300

column9: because Mr. Apple doesn\'t like to eat the same food. For each pair of dishes from different days he remembers exactly which was better

column12: that serves chestnut soup with fir
column13: warm soda bread
column14: spicy lemon pie and other folk food

column17: in which he described his impressions. If
column18: according to the expert
column19: dish i from the first set was better than dish j from the second set

column21: in the opposite case aij is equal to ""<"". Dishes also may be equally good
column22: in this case aij is ""="".Now Mr. Apple wants you to help him to evaluate every dish. Since Mr. Apple is very strict
column23: he will evaluate the dishes so that the maximal number used is as small as possible. But Mr. Apple also is very fair

column3: sortings" "Cowboy Vlad has a birthday today! There are n children who came to the celebration. In order to greet Vlad
column4: the children decided to form a circle around him. Among the children who came
column5: there are both tall and low
column6: so if they stand in a circle arbitrarily
column7: it may turn out
column8: that there is a tall and low child standing next to each other
column9: and it will be difficult for them to hold hands. Therefore
column10: children want to stand in a circle so that the maximum difference between the growth of two neighboring children would be minimal possible.Formally

column12: that is
column13: for every i child with number i will stand next to the child with number i+1
column14: also the child with number 1 stands next to the child with number n. Then we will call the discomfort of the circle the maximum absolute difference of heights of the children
column15: who stand next to each other.Please help children to find out how they should reorder themselves
column16: so that the resulting discomfort is smallest possible." 1200

column1: 1121C "System Testing" implementation "Vasya likes taking part in Codeforces contests. When a round is over
column2: Vasya follows all submissions in the system testing tab.There are n solutions
column3: the i-th of them should be tested on ai tests
column4: testing one solution on one test takes 1 second. The solutions are judged in the order from 1 to n. There are k testing processes which test solutions simultaneously. Each of them can test at most one solution at a time.At any time moment t when some testing process is not judging any solution
column5: it takes the first solution from the queue and tests it on each test in increasing order of the test ids. Let this solution have id i
column6: then it is being tested on the first test from time moment t till time moment t+1
column7: then on the second test till time moment t+2 and so on. This solution is fully tested at time moment t+ai
column8: and after that the testing process immediately starts testing another solution.Consider some time moment
column9: let there be exactly m fully tested solutions by this moment. There is a caption ""System testing: d%"" on the page with solutions
column10: where d is calculated asd=round(100\xe2\x8b\x85mn)
column11: where round(x)=\xe2\x8c\x8ax+0.5\xe2\x8c\x8b is a function which maps every real to the nearest integer.Vasya calls a submission interesting if there is a time moment (possibly
column12: non-integer) when the solution is being tested on some test q
column13: and the caption says ""System testing: q%"". Find the number of interesting solutions.Please note that in case when multiple processes attempt to take the first submission from the queue at the same moment (for instance
column14: at the initial moment)
column15: the order they take the solutions does not matter." 1600

column5: but Alyona can install arbitrary number of shelves inside the fridge between any two rows. A shelf is two cells wide
column6: does not occupy any space but separates the inside of the fridge to the lower and upper part.  An example of a fridge with h=7 and two shelves. The shelves are shown in black. The picture corresponds to the first example. Alyona has n bottles of milk that she wants to put in the fridge. The i-th bottle is ai cells tall and 1 cell wide. She can put a bottle on some shelf if the corresponding space above the shelf is at least as tall as the bottle. She can not put a bottle on top of another bottle (if there is no shelf between them). Two bottles can not share a cell.Alyona is interested in the largest integer k such that she can put bottles 1
column9: k in the fridge at the same time. Find this largest k." 1300

column13: find this maximum possible distance." 1100

column4: trees" "You are given an undirected tree of n vertices. Some vertices are colored one of the k colors
column5: some are uncolored. It is guaranteed that the tree contains at least one vertex of each of the k colors. There might be no uncolored vertices.You choose a subset of exactly k\xe2\x88\x921 edges and remove it from the tree. Tree falls apart into k connected components. Let\'s call this subset of edges nice if none of the resulting components contain vertices of different colors.How many nice subsets of edges are there in the given tree? Two subsets are considered different if there is some edge that is present in one subset and absent in the other.The answer may be large
column6: so print it modulo 998244353." 2700

column2: trees" "You are given an undirected tree of n vertices. Some vertices are colored blue
column3: some are colored red and some are uncolored. It is guaranteed that the tree contains at least one red vertex and at least one blue vertex.You choose an edge and remove it from the tree. Tree falls apart into two connected components. Let\'s call an edge nice if neither of the resulting components contain vertices of both red and blue colors.How many nice edges are there in the given tree?" 1800

column14: i.e. for every i from 1 to n\xe2\x88\x921 the conditions bi\xe2\x89\xa0bi+1 and gi\xe2\x89\xa0gi+1 hold. Let\'s take a look at the examples of bad and good color choosing (for n=4 and k=3

column1: 1118B "Tanya and Candies" implementation "Tanya has n candies numbered from 1 to n. The i-th candy has the weight ai.She plans to eat exactly n\xe2\x88\x921 candies and give the remaining candy to her dad. Tanya eats candies in order of increasing their numbers
column2: exactly one candy per day.Your task is to find the number of such candies i (let\'s call these candies good) that if dad gets the i-th candy then the sum of weights of candies Tanya eats in even days will be equal to the sum of weights of candies Tanya eats in odd days. Note that at first
column3: she will give the candy
column4: after it she will eat the remaining candies one by one.For example
column5: n=4 and weights are [1
column8: 3]. Consider all possible cases to give a candy to dad:  Tanya gives the 1-st candy to dad (a1=1)
column9: the remaining candies are [4
column11: 3]. She will eat a2=4 in the first day
column12: a3=3 in the second day
column13: a4=3 in the third day. So in odd days she will eat 4+3=7 and in even days she will eat 3. Since 7\xe2\x89\xa03 this case shouldn\'t be counted to the answer (this candy isn\'t good).  Tanya gives the 2-nd candy to dad (a2=4)
column14: the remaining candies are [1
column16: 3]. She will eat a1=1 in the first day
column17: a3=3 in the second day
column18: a4=3 in the third day. So in odd days she will eat 1+3=4 and in even days she will eat 3. Since 4\xe2\x89\xa03 this case shouldn\'t be counted to the answer (this candy isn\'t good).  Tanya gives the 3-rd candy to dad (a3=3)
column19: the remaining candies are [1
column21: 3]. She will eat a1=1 in the first day
column22: a2=4 in the second day
column23: a4=3 in the third day. So in odd days she will eat 1+3=4 and in even days she will eat 4. Since 4=4 this case should be counted to the answer (this candy is good).  Tanya gives the 4-th candy to dad (a4=3)
column24: the remaining candies are [1
column26: 3]. She will eat a1=1 in the first day
column27: a2=4 in the second day
column28: a3=3 in the third day. So in odd days she will eat 1+3=4 and in even days she will eat 4. Since 4=4 this case should be counted to the answer (this candy is good). In total there 2 cases which should counted (these candies are good)
column29: so the answer is 2." 1200

You also have to answer q independent queries." 800

column2: dp "You are given a string of length n. Each character is one of the first p lowercase Latin letters.You are also given a matrix A with binary values of size p\xc3\x97p. This matrix is symmetric (Aij=Aji). Aij=1 means that the string can have the i-th and j-th letters of Latin alphabet adjacent.Let\'s call the string crisp if all of the adjacent characters in it can be adjacent (have 1 in the corresponding cell of matrix A).You are allowed to do the following move. Choose any letter
column3: remove all its occurrences and join the remaining parts of the string without changing their order. For example
column4: removing letter \'a\' from ""abacaba"" will yield ""bcb"".The string you are given is crisp. The string should remain crisp after every move you make.You are allowed to do arbitrary number of moves (possible zero). What is the shortest resulting string you can obtain?" 2500

column3: constructive algorithms
column4: interactive
column5: math" "This is an interactive problem. Remember to flush your output while communicating with the testing program. You may use fflush(stdout) in C++
column6: system.out.flush() in Java
column7: stdout.flush() in Python or flush(output) in Pascal to flush the output. If you use some other programming language
column8: consult its documentation. You may also refer to the guide on interactive problems: https://codeforces.com/blog/entry/45307.You are given a string t consisting of n lowercase Latin letters. This string was cyphered as follows: initially
column9: the jury had a string s consisting of n lowercase Latin letters. Then they applied a sequence of no more than n (possibly zero) operations. i-th operation is denoted by two integers ai and bi (1\xe2\x89\xa4ai
column10: bi\xe2\x89\xa4n)
column11: and means swapping two elements of the string with indices ai and bi. All operations were done in the order they were placed in the sequence. For example
column12: if s is xyz and 2 following operations are performed: a1=1
column15: then after the first operation the current string is yxz
column16: and after the second operation the current string is yzx
column17: so t is yzx.You are asked to restore the original string s. Unfortunately
column18: you have no information about the operations used in the algorithm (you don\'t even know if there were any operations in the sequence). But you may run the same sequence of operations on any string you want
column19: provided that it contains only lowercase Latin letters and its length is n
column20: and get the resulting string after those operations.Can you guess the original string s asking the testing system to run the sequence of swaps no more than 3 times?The string s and the sequence of swaps are fixed in each test; the interactor doesn\'t try to adapt the test to your solution." 2200

column3: matrices "Reziba has many magic gems. Each magic gem can be split into M normal gems. The amount of space each magic (and normal) gem takes is 1 unit. A normal gem cannot be split.Reziba wants to choose a set of magic gems and split some of them
column4: so the total space occupied by the resulting set of gems is N units. If a magic gem is chosen and split
column5: it takes M units of space (since it is split into M gems); if a magic gem is not split
column6: it takes 1 unit.How many different configurations of the resulting set of gems can Reziba have
column7: such that the total amount of space taken is N units? Print the answer modulo 1000000007 (109+7). Two configurations are considered different if the number of magic gems Reziba takes to form them differs
column8: or the indices of gems Reziba has to split differ." 2100

column3: sortings "There are n emotes in very popular digital collectible card game (the game is pretty famous so we won\'t say its name). The i-th emote increases the opponent\'s happiness by ai units (we all know that emotes in this game are used to make opponents happy).You have time to use some emotes only m times. You are allowed to use any emotion once
column4: more than once
column5: or not use it at all. The only restriction is that you cannot use the same emote more than k times in a row (otherwise the opponent will think that you\'re trolling him).Note that two emotes i and j (i\xe2\x89\xa0j) such that ai=aj are considered different.You have to make your opponent as happy as possible. Find the maximum possible opponent\'s happiness." 1000

column1: 1116D6 "Hessenberg matrix" NA "Implement a unitary operation on N qubits which is represented by an upper Hessenberg matrix (a square matrix of size 2N which has all zero elements below the first subdiagonal and all non-zero elements on the first subdiagonal and above it).For example
column2: for N=2 the matrix of the operation should have the following shape:XXXXXXXX.XXX..XXHere X denotes a ""non-zero"" element of the matrix (a complex number which has the square of the absolute value greater than or equal to 10\xe2\x88\x925)
column3: and . denotes a ""zero"" element of the matrix (a complex number which has the square of the absolute value less than 10\xe2\x88\x925).The row and column indices of the matrix follow little endian format: the least significant bit of the index is stored first in the qubit array. Thus
column4: the first column of the matrix gives you the coefficients of the basis states you\'ll get if you apply the unitary to the |00..0\xe2\x9f\xa9 basis state
column5: the second column - to the |10..0\xe2\x9f\xa9 basis state etc. You can use the DumpUnitary tool to get the coefficients of the matrix your unitary implements (up to relative phases between columns) and the corresponding pattern of Xs and .s.You have to implement an operation which takes an array of N (2\xe2\x89\xa4N\xe2\x89\xa44) qubits as an input and applies the unitary transformation with the matrix of the described shape to it. If there are multiple unitaries which satisfy the requirements
column6: you can implement any of them. The ""output"" of your operation is the pattern of the matrix coefficients implemented by it; you can see the testing harness in the UnitaryPatterns kata.Your code should have the following signature:namespace Solution {    open Microsoft.Quantum.Primitive;    open Microsoft.Quantum.Canon;    operation Solve (qs : Qubit[]) : Unit {        // your code here    }}You are not allowed to use measurements in your operation." -999

column3: and . denotes a ""zero"" element of the matrix (a complex number which has the square of the absolute value less than 10\xe2\x88\x925).The row and column indices of the matrix follow little endian format: the least significant bit of the index is stored first in the qubit array. Thus
column4: the first column of the matrix gives you the coefficients of the basis states you\'ll get if you apply the unitary to the |00..0\xe2\x9f\xa9 basis state
column5: the second column - to the |10..0\xe2\x9f\xa9 basis state etc. You can use the DumpUnitary tool to get the coefficients of the matrix your unitary implements (up to relative phases between columns) and the corresponding pattern of Xs and .s.You have to implement an operation which takes an array of N (2\xe2\x89\xa4N\xe2\x89\xa45) qubits as an input and applies the unitary transformation with the matrix of the described shape to it. If there are multiple unitaries which satisfy the requirements
column6: you can implement any of them. The ""output"" of your operation is the pattern of the matrix coefficients implemented by it; you can see the testing harness in the UnitaryPatterns kata.Your code should have the following signature:namespace Solution {    open Microsoft.Quantum.Primitive;    open Microsoft.Quantum.Canon;    operation Solve (qs : Qubit[]) : Unit {        // your code here    }}You are not allowed to use measurements in your operation." -999

column2: not B or not C?" NA "You are given a qubit which is guaranteed to be in one of the following states: |A\xe2\x9f\xa9=1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|0\xe2\x9f\xa9+|1\xe2\x9f\xa9)
column3: |B\xe2\x9f\xa9=1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|0\xe2\x9f\xa9+\xcf\x89|1\xe2\x9f\xa9)
column4: or |C\xe2\x9f\xa9=1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|0\xe2\x9f\xa9+\xcf\x892|1\xe2\x9f\xa9)
column5: where \xcf\x89=e2i\xcf\x80/3.These states are not orthogonal
column6: and thus can not be distinguished perfectly. Your task is to figure out in which state the qubit is not. More formally: If the qubit was in state |A\xe2\x9f\xa9
column7: you have to return 1 or 2. If the qubit was in state |B\xe2\x9f\xa9
column8: you have to return 0 or 2. If the qubit was in state |C\xe2\x9f\xa9
column9: you have to return 0 or 1. In other words
column10: return 0 if you\'re sure the qubit was not in state |A\xe2\x9f\xa9
column11: return 1 if you\'re sure the qubit was not in state |B\xe2\x9f\xa9
column12: and return 2 if you\'re sure the qubit was not in state |C\xe2\x9f\xa9.Your solution will be called 1000 times
column13: each time the state of the qubit will be chosen as |A\xe2\x9f\xa9
column14: |B\xe2\x9f\xa9 or |C\xe2\x9f\xa9 with equal probability. The state of the qubit after the operations does not matter.You have to implement an operation which takes a qubit as an input and returns an integer. Your code should have the following signature:namespace Solution {    open Microsoft.Quantum.Primitive;    open Microsoft.Quantum.Canon;    operation Solve (q : Qubit) : Int {        // your code here    }}" -999

column1: 1116B1 "Distinguish three-qubit states" NA "You are given 3 qubits which are guaranteed to be in one of the two states: |\xcf\x880\xe2\x9f\xa9=1\xe2\x88\x9a3(|100\xe2\x9f\xa9+\xcf\x89|010\xe2\x9f\xa9+\xcf\x892|001\xe2\x9f\xa9)
column3: where \xcf\x89=e2i\xcf\x80/3.Your task is to perform necessary operations and measurements to figure out which state it was and to return 0 if it was |\xcf\x880\xe2\x9f\xa9 state or 1 if it was |\xcf\x881\xe2\x9f\xa9 state. The state of the qubits after the operations does not matter.You have to implement an operation which takes an array of 3 qubits as an input and returns an integer. column3: bottom right quarter is filled with non-zero elements.For example
column4: for N=2 the matrix of the operation should have the following shape:.X..X.....XX..XXHere X denotes a ""non-zero"" element of the matrix (a complex number which has the square of the absolute value greater than or equal to 10\xe2\x88\x925)

column4: probabilities" "This is an interactive problem!An arithmetic progression or arithmetic sequence is a sequence of integers such that the subtraction of element with its previous element (xi\xe2\x88\x92xi\xe2\x88\x921
column5: where i\xe2\x89\xa52) is constantÂ \xe2\x80\x94 such difference is called a common difference of the sequence.That is
column6: an arithmetic progression is a sequence of form xi=x1+(i\xe2\x88\x921)d
column7: where d is a common difference of the sequence.There is a secret list of n integers a1

column24: which can be produced as xn=9+5\xe2\x8b\x85(n\xe2\x88\x921).Also you are also given a device

column1: 1114D "Flood Fill" dp "You are given a line of n colored squares in a row
column2: numbered from 1 to n from left to right. The i-th square initially has the color ci.Let\'s say
column3: that two squares i and j belong to the same connected component if ci=cj
column4: and ci=ck for all k satisfying i<k<j. In other words
column5: all squares on the segment from i to j should have the same color.For example
column6: the line [3
column8: 3] has 1 connected component
column9: while the line [5
column12: 4] has 3 connected components.The game ""flood fill"" is played on the given line as follows:   At the start of the game you pick any starting square (this is not counted as a turn).  Then
column13: in each game turn
column14: change the color of the connected component containing the starting square to any other color. Find the minimum number of turns needed for the entire line to be changed into a single color." 1900

column4: number theory" "The number ""zero"" is called ""love"" (or ""l\'oeuf"" to be precise
column5: literally means ""egg"" in French)
column6: for example when denoting the zero score in a game of tennis. Aki is fond of numbers
column7: especially those with trailing zeros. For example
column8: the number 9200 has two trailing zeros. Aki thinks the more trailing zero digits a number has
column9: the prettier it is.However
column10: Aki believes
column11: that the number of trailing zeros of a number is not static
column12: but depends on the base (radix) it is represented in. Thus
column13: he considers a few scenarios with some numbers and bases. And now
column14: since the numbers he used become quite bizarre
column15: he asks you to help him to calculate the beauty of these numbers.Given two integers n and b (in decimal notation)
column16: your task is to calculate the number of trailing zero digits in the b-ary (in the base/radix of b) representation of n! (factorial of n)." 1700

column3: implementation" "The Duck songFor simplicity
column4: we\'ll assume that there are only three types of grapes: green grapes
column5: purple grapes and black grapes.Andrew
column6: Dmitry and Michal are all grapes\' lovers
column7: however their preferences of grapes are different. To make all of them happy
column8: the following should happen: Andrew
column9: Dmitry and Michal should eat at least x
column10: y and z grapes
column11: respectively. Andrew has an extreme affinity for green grapes
column12: thus he will eat green grapes and green grapes only. On the other hand
column13: Dmitry is not a fan of black grapesÂ \xe2\x80\x94 any types of grapes except black would do for him. In other words
column14: Dmitry can eat green and purple grapes. Michal has a common tasteÂ \xe2\x80\x94 he enjoys grapes in general and will be pleased with any types of grapes
column15: as long as the quantity is sufficient.Knowing that his friends are so fond of grapes
column16: Aki decided to host a grape party with them. He has prepared a box with a green grapes
column17: b purple grapes and c black grapes.However
column18: Aki isn\'t sure if the box he prepared contains enough grapes to make everyone happy. Can you please find out whether it\'s possible to distribute grapes so that everyone is happy or Aki has to buy some more grapes?It is not required to distribute all the grapes
column19: so it\'s possible that some of them will remain unused." 800

column2: number theory" "One day Sasha visited the farmer 2D and his famous magnetic farm. On this farm

column2: trees" "Let\'s define the Eulerian traversal of a tree (a connected undirected graph without cycles) as follows: consider a depth-first search algorithm which traverses vertices of the tree and enumerates them in the order of visiting (only the first visit of each vertex counts). This function starts from the vertex number 1 and then recursively runs from all vertices which are connected with an edge with the current vertex and are not yet visited in increasing numbers order. Formally
column3: you can describe this function using the following pseudocode:next_id = 1id = array of length n filled with -1visited = array of length n filled with falsefunction dfs(v):    visited[v] = true    id[v] = next_id    next_id += 1    for to in neighbors of v in increasing order:        if not visited[to]:            dfs(to)You are given a weighted tree
column4: the vertices of which were enumerated with integers from 1 to n using the algorithm described above.A leaf is a vertex of the tree which is connected with only one other vertex. In the tree given to you
column5: the vertex 1 is not a leaf. The distance between two vertices in the tree is the sum of weights of the edges on the simple path between them.You have to answer q queries of the following type: given integers v
column6: l and r
column7: find the shortest distance from vertex v to one of the leaves with indices from l to r inclusive." 2600

column3: strings" "Reading books is one of Sasha\'s passions. Once while he was reading one book
column4: he became acquainted with an unusual character. The character told about himself like that: ""Many are my names in many countries. Mithrandir among the Elves
column5: Thark\xc3\xbbn to the Dwarves
column6: Ol\xc3\xb3rin I was in my youth in the West that is forgotten
column7: in the South Inc\xc3\xa1nus
column8: in the North Gandalf; to the East I go not.""And at that moment Sasha thought
column9: how would that character be called in the East? In the East all names are palindromes. A string is a palindrome if it reads the same backward as forward. For example
column10: such strings as ""kazak""
column11: ""oo"" and ""r"" are palindromes
column12: but strings ""abb"" and ""ij"" are not. Sasha believed that the hero would be named after one of the gods of the East. As long as there couldn\'t be two equal names
column13: so in the East people did the following: they wrote the original name as a string on a piece of paper
column14: then cut the paper minimum number of times k
column15: so they got k+1 pieces of paper with substrings of the initial string
column16: and then unite those pieces together to get a new string. Pieces couldn\'t be turned over
column17: they could be shuffled.In this way
column18: it\'s possible to achive a string abcdefg from the string f|de|abc|g using 3 cuts (by swapping papers with substrings f and abc). The string cbadefg can\'t be received using the same cuts.More formally
column19: Sasha wants for the given palindrome s find such minimum k
column20: that you can cut this string into k+1 parts
column21: and then unite them in such a way that the final string will be a palindrome and it won\'t be equal to the initial string s. It there is no answer
column22: then print ""Impossible"" (without quotes)." 1800

column6: S(10)=S(1+0=1)=1.As a homework Petya got n tasks of the form: find k-th positive number whose digital root is x.Petya has already solved all the problems
column7: but he doesn\'t know if it\'s right. Your task is to solve all n tasks from Petya\'s homework." 1000

column1: 1106B "Lunar New Year and Food Ordering" "data structures
column3: and Bob is planning to go for a famous restaurant \xe2\x80\x94 ""Alice\'s"".The restaurant ""Alice\'s"" serves n kinds of food. The cost for the i-th kind is always ci. Initially
column4: the restaurant has enough ingredients for serving exactly ai dishes of the i-th kind. In the New Year\'s Eve
column5: m customers will visit Alice\'s one after another and the j-th customer will order dj dishes of the tj-th kind of food. The (i+1)-st customer will only come after the i-th customer is completely served.Suppose there are ri dishes of the i-th kind remaining (initially ri=ai). When a customer orders 1 dish of the i-th kind
column6: the following principles will be processed. If ri>0
column7: the customer will be served exactly 1 dish of the i-th kind. The cost for the dish is ci. Meanwhile
column8: ri will be reduced by 1. Otherwise
column9: the customer will be served 1 dish of the cheapest available kind of food if there are any. If there are multiple cheapest kinds of food
column10: the one with the smallest index among the cheapest will be served. The cost will be the cost for the dish served and the remain for the corresponding dish will be reduced by 1. If there are no more dishes at all
column11: the customer will leave angrily. Therefore
column12: no matter how many dishes are served previously
column13: the cost for the customer is 0.If the customer doesn\'t leave after the dj dishes are served
column14: the cost for the customer will be the sum of the cost for these dj dishes.Please determine the total cost for each of the m customers." 1500

One solved problem increases the skill by one.The coach wants to know the minimum total number of problems students should solve to form exactly n2 teams (i.e. each pair of students should form a team). Your task is to find this number." 800

column1: 1092A "Uniform String" implementation "You are given two integers n and k.Your task is to construct such a string s of length n that for each i from 1 to k there is at least one i-th letter of the Latin alphabet in this string (the first letter is \'a\'
column2: the second is \'b\' and so on) and there are no other letters except these. You have to maximize the minimal frequency of some letter (the frequency of a letter is the number of occurrences of this letter in a string). If there are several possible answers
column3: you can print any.You have to answer t independent queries." 800

column1: 1091H "New Year and the Tricolore Recreation" games "Alice and Bob play a game on a grid with n rows and infinitely many columns. In each row
column3: blue
column4: white and red one. Before the game starts and after every move
column5: the following two conditions must hold:   Any two tokens are not in the same cell.  In each row
column6: the blue token is to the left of the white token
column7: and the red token is to the right of the white token. First
column8: they pick a positive integer f
column9: whose value is valid for the whole game. Second
column10: the starting player is chosen and makes his or her first turn. Then players take alternating turns. The player who is unable to make a move loses. During a move
column11: a player first selects an integer k that is either a prime number or a product of two (not necessarily distinct) primes. The smallest possible values of k are thus 2
column25: \xe2\x80\xa6. Furthermore
column26: k must not be equal to the previously picked integer f. Each turn
column27: a move is performed in exactly one of the rows.If it is Alice\'s turn
column28: she chooses a single blue token and moves it k cells to the right. Alternatively
column29: she may move both the blue and the white token in the same row by the same amount k to the right.On the other hand
column30: Bob selects a single red token and moves it k cells to the left. Similarly
column31: he may also move the white and the red token in the corresponding row by k to the left.Note that Alice may never move a red token
column32: while Bob may never move a blue one. Remember that after a move
column33: the two conditions on relative positions of the tokens must still hold. Both players play optimally. Given the initial state of the board
column34: determine who wins for two games: if Alice starts and if Bob starts." 3200

column3: number theory" "Integer factorisation is hard. The RSA Factoring Challenge offered $100000 for factoring RSA-1024
column4: a 1024-bit long product of two prime numbers. To this date
column5: nobody was able to claim the prize. We want you to factorise a 1024-bit number.Since your programming language of choice might not offer facilities for handling large integers
column6: we will provide you with a very simple calculator. To use this calculator
column7: you can print queries on the standard output and retrieve the results from the standard input. The operations are as follows:   + x y where x and y are integers between 0 and n\xe2\x88\x921. Returns (x+y)modn.  - x y where x and y are integers between 0 and n\xe2\x88\x921. Returns (x\xe2\x88\x92y)modn.  * x y where x and y are integers between 0 and n\xe2\x88\x921. Returns (x\xe2\x8b\x85y)modn.  / x y where x and y are integers between 0 and n\xe2\x88\x921 and y is coprime with n. Returns (x\xe2\x8b\x85y\xe2\x88\x921)modn where y\xe2\x88\x921 is multiplicative inverse of y modulo n. If y is not coprime with n
column8: then \xe2\x88\x921 is returned instead.  sqrt x where x is integer between 0 and n\xe2\x88\x921 coprime with n. Returns y such that y2modn=x. If there are multiple such integers
column9: only one of them is returned. If there are none
column10: \xe2\x88\x921 is returned instead.  ^ x y where x and y are integers between 0 and n\xe2\x88\x921. Returns xymodn. Find the factorisation of n that is a product of between 2 and 10 distinct prime numbers
column11: all of form 4x+3 for some integer x.Because of technical issues
column12: we restrict number of requests to 100." 3200

column1: 1091F "New Year and the Mallard Expedition" "constructive algorithms
column2: greedy" "Bob is a duck. He wants to get to Alice\'s nest
column3: so that those two can duck!  Duck is the ultimate animal! (Image courtesy of See Bang) The journey can be represented as a straight line
column4: consisting of n segments. Bob is located to the left of the first segment
column5: while Alice\'s nest is on the right of the last segment. Each segment has a length in meters
column6: and also terrain type: grass
column7: water or lava. Bob has three movement types: swimming
column8: walking and flying. He can switch between them or change his direction at any point in time (even when he is located at a non-integer coordinate)
column9: and doing so doesn\'t require any extra time. Bob can swim only on the water
column10: walk only on the grass and fly over any terrain. Flying one meter takes 1 second
column11: swimming one meter takes 3 seconds
column12: and finally walking one meter takes 5 seconds.Bob has a finite amount of energy
column13: called stamina. Swimming and walking is relaxing for him
column14: so he gains 1 stamina for every meter he walks or swims. On the other hand
column15: flying is quite tiring
column16: and he spends 1 stamina for every meter flown. Staying in place does not influence his stamina at all. Of course
column17: his stamina can never become negative. Initially
column18: his stamina is zero.What is the shortest possible time in which he can reach Alice\'s nest?" 2600

column2: number theory" "There are n people sitting in a circle
column3: numbered from 1 to n in the order in which they are seated. That is
column4: for all i from 1 to n\xe2\x88\x921
column5: the people with id i and i+1 are adjacent. People with id n and 1 are adjacent as well.The person with id 1 initially has a ball. He picks a positive integer k at most n
column6: and passes the ball to his k-th neighbour in the direction of increasing ids
column7: that person passes the ball to his k-th neighbour in the same direction
column8: and so on until the person with the id 1 gets the ball back. When he gets it back
column9: people do not pass the ball any more.For instance
column10: if n=6 and k=4
column11: the ball is passed in order [1
column14: 1]. Consider the set of all people that touched the ball. The fun value of the game is the sum of the ids of people that touched it. In the above example
column15: the fun value would be 1+5+3=9.Find and report the set of possible fun values for all choices of positive integer k. It can be shown that under the constraints of the problem
column16: the ball always gets back to the 1-st player after finitely many steps
column17: and there are no more than 105 possible fun values for given n." 1400

The clues must be distributed among the obelisks in such a way that they all point to the same position of the treasure.Your task is to find the coordinates of the treasure. column8: if they have 8 yellow ornaments
column9: 13 blue ornaments and 9 red ornaments

column2: data structures" "Santa has prepared boxes with presents for n kids

column2: implementation "International Coding Procedures Company (ICPC) writes all its code in Jedi Script (JS) programming language. JS does not get compiled
column3: but is delivered for execution in its source form. Sources contain comments
column4: extra whitespace (including trailing and leading spaces)
column5: and other non-essential features that make them quite large but do not contribute to the semantics of the code
column6: so the process of minification is performed on source files before their delivery to execution to compress sources while preserving their semantics.You are hired by ICPC to write JS minifier for ICPC. Fortunately
column7: ICPC adheres to very strict programming practices and their JS sources are quite restricted in grammar. They work only on integer algorithms and do not use floating point numbers and strings. Every JS source contains a sequence of lines. Each line contains zero or more tokens that can be separated by spaces. On each line
column8: a part of the line that starts with a hash character (\'#\' code 35)
column9: including the hash character itself
column10: is treated as a comment and is ignored up to the end of the line.Each line is parsed into a sequence of tokens from left to right by repeatedly skipping spaces and finding the longest possible token starting at the current parsing position
column11: thus transforming the source code into a sequence of tokens. All the possible tokens are listed below:  A reserved token is any kind of operator
column12: separator
column13: literal
column14: reserved word
column15: or a name of a library function that should be preserved during the minification process. Reserved tokens are fixed strings of non-space ASCII characters that do not contain the hash character (\'#\' code 35). All reserved tokens are given as an input to the minification process.  A number token consists of a sequence of digits
column16: where a digit is a character from zero (\'0\') to nine (\'9\') inclusive.  A word token consists of a sequence of characters from the following set: lowercase letters
column17: uppercase letters
column18: digits
column19: underscore (\'_\' code 95)
column20: and dollar sign (\'$\' code 36). A word does not start with a digit. Note
column21: that during parsing the longest sequence of characters that satisfies either a number or a word definition
column22: but that appears in the list of reserved tokens
column23: is considered to be a reserved token instead.During the minification process words are renamed in a systematic fashion using the following algorithm:  Take a list of words that consist only of lowercase letters ordered first by their length
column24: then lexicographically: ""a""
column31: excluding reserved tokens
column32: since they are not considered to be words. This is the target word list.  Rename the first word encountered in the input token sequence to the first word in the target word list and all further occurrences of the same word in the input token sequence
column33: too. Rename the second new word encountered in the input token sequence to the second word in the target word list
column34: and so on. The goal of the minification process is to convert the given source to the shortest possible line (counting spaces) that still parses to the same sequence of tokens with the correspondingly renamed words using these JS parsing rules." 3200

column3: dp" "Petya collects beautiful matrix.A matrix of size n\xc3\x97n is beautiful if:   All elements of the matrix are integers between 1 and n;  For every row of the matrix

column1: 1085F "Rock-Paper-Scissors Champion" NA "n players are going to play a rock-paper-scissors tournament. As you probably know
column2: in a one-on-one match of rock-paper-scissors
column3: two players choose their shapes independently. The outcome is then determined depending on the chosen shapes: ""paper"" beats ""rock""
column4: ""rock"" beats ""scissors""
column5: ""scissors"" beat ""paper""
column6: and two equal shapes result in a draw.At the start of the tournament all players will stand in a row
column7: with their numbers increasing from 1 for the leftmost player
column8: to n for the rightmost player. Each player has a pre-chosen shape that they will use in every game throughout the tournament. Here\'s how the tournament is conducted: If there is only one player left
column9: he is declared the champion. Otherwise
column10: two adjacent players in the row are chosen arbitrarily
column11: and they play the next match. The losing player is eliminated from the tournament and leaves his place in the row (with his former neighbours becoming adjacent). If the game is a draw
column12: the losing player is determined by a coin toss.The organizers are informed about all players\' favoured shapes. They wish to find out the total number of players who have a chance of becoming the tournament champion (that is
column13: there is a suitable way to choose the order of the games and manipulate the coin tosses). However
column14: some players are still optimizing their strategy
column15: and can inform the organizers about their new shapes. Can you find the number of possible champions after each such request?" 2500

column3: trees" "You are given a tree (an undirected connected graph without cycles) and an integer s.Vanya wants to put weights on all edges of the tree so that all weights are non-negative real numbers and their sum is s. At the same time
column4: he wants to make the diameter of the tree as small as possible.Let\'s define the diameter of a weighed tree as the maximum sum of the weights of the edges lying on the path between two some vertices of the tree. In other words
column5: the diameter of a weighed tree is the length of the longest simple path in the tree
column6: where length of a path is equal to the sum of weights over all edges in the path.Find the minimum possible diameter that Vanya can get." 1700

column2: strings "Polycarp loves ciphers. He has invented his own cipher called Right-Left.Right-Left cipher is used for strings. To encrypt the string s=s1s2\xe2\x80\xa6sn Polycarp uses the following algorithm:  he writes down s1
column3: he appends the current word with s2 (i.e. writes down s2 to the right of the current result)
column4: he prepends the current word with s3 (i.e. writes down s3 to the left of the current result)
column5: he appends the current word with s4 (i.e. writes down s4 to the right of the current result)
column6: he prepends the current word with s5 (i.e. writes down s5 to the left of the current result)
column7: and so on for each position until the end of s. For example
column8: if s=""techno"" the process is: ""t"" \xe2\x86\x92 ""te"" \xe2\x86\x92 ""cte"" \xe2\x86\x92 ""cteh"" \xe2\x86\x92 ""ncteh"" \xe2\x86\x92 ""ncteho"". So the encrypted s=""techno"" is ""ncteho"".Given string t \xe2\x80\x94 the result of encryption of some string s. Your task is to decrypt it
column9: i.e. find the string s." 800

column2: strings "You are given a string s
column3: consisting of n lowercase Latin letters.A substring of string s is a continuous segment of letters from s. For example
column4: ""defor"" is a substring of ""codeforces"" and ""fors"" is not. The length of the substring is the number of letters in it.Let\'s call some string of length n diverse if and only if there is no letter to appear strictly more than n2 times. For example
column5: strings ""abc"" and ""iltlml"" are diverse and strings ""aab"" and ""zz"" are not.Your task is to find any diverse substring of string s or report that there is none. Note that it is not required to maximize or minimize the length of the resulting substring." 1000

column2: geometry" "A lot of people dream of convertibles (also often called cabriolets). Some of convertibles
column3: however
column4: don\'t have roof at all
column5: and are vulnerable to rain. This is why Melon Ask
column6: the famous inventor
column7: decided to create a rain protection mechanism for convertibles.The workplace of the mechanism is a part of plane just above the driver. Its functional part consists of two rails with sliding endpoints of a piece of stretching rope. For the sake of simplicity we can consider this as a pair of parallel segments in a plane with the rope segment
column8: whose endpoints we are free to choose as any points on these rails segments.  The algorithmic part of the mechanism detects each particular raindrop and predicts when and where it reaches the plane. At this exact moment the rope segment must contain the raindrop point (so the rope adsorbs the raindrop).You are given the initial position of the rope endpoints and all information about raindrops. You are to choose the minimal possible speed v of the endpoints sliding (both endpoints can slide in any direction along their segments independently of each other) in such a way that it is possible to catch all raindrops moving both endpoints with speed not greater than v
column9: or find out that it\'s impossible no matter how high the speed is." 3500

column3: geometry" "Once upon a time Algoland and Berland were a single country
column4: but those times are long gone. Now they are two different countries
column5: but their cities are scattered on a common territory.All cities are represented as points on the Cartesian plane. Algoland consists of a cities numbered from 1 to a. The coordinates of the i-th Algoland city are a pair of integer numbers (xai
column6: yai). Similarly
column7: Berland consists of b cities numbered from 1 to b. The coordinates of the j-th Berland city are a pair of integer numbers (xbj
column8: ybj). No three of the a+b mentioned cities lie on a single straight line.As the first step to unite the countries
column9: Berland decided to build several bidirectional freeways. Each freeway is going to be a line segment that starts in a Berland city and ends in an Algoland city. Freeways can\'t intersect with each other at any point except freeway\'s start or end. Moreover
column10: the freeways have to connect all a+b cities. Here
column11: connectivity means that one can get from any of the specified a+b cities to any other of the a+b cities using freeways. Note that all freeways are bidirectional
column12: which means that one can drive on each of them in both directions.Mayor of each of the b Berland cities allocated a budget to build the freeways that start from this city. Thus
column13: you are given the numbers r1
column14: r2
column15: \xe2\x80\xa6
column16: rb
column17: where rj is the number of freeways that are going to start in the j-th Berland city. The total allocated budget is very tight and only covers building the minimal necessary set of freeways. In other words
column18: r1+r2+\xe2\x8b\xaf+rb=a+b\xe2\x88\x921.Help Berland to build the freeways so that:  each freeway is a line segment connecting a Berland city and an Algoland city
column19: no freeways intersect with each other except for the freeway\'s start or end
column20: freeways connect all a+b cities (all freeways are bidirectional)
column21: there are rj freeways that start from the j-th Berland city." 3000

column1: 1070J "Streets and Avenues in Berhattan" dp "Berhattan is the capital of Berland. There are n streets running parallel in the east-west direction (horizontally)
column2: and there are m avenues running parallel in the south-north direction (vertically). Each street intersects with each avenue
column3: forming a crossroad. So in total there are n\xe2\x8b\x85m crossroads in Berhattan.Recently
column4: the government has changed in Berland. The new government wants to name all avenues and all streets after heroes of revolution.The special committee prepared the list of k names. Only these names can be used as new names for streets and avenues. Each name can be used at most once.The members of committee want to name streets and avenues in the way that minimizes inconvenience for residents. They believe that if street and avenue names start with the same letter
column5: then their crossroad will be inconvenient. Hence only the first letter of each name matters.Given first letters of k names
column6: find C \xe2\x80\x94 minimal possible number of inconvenient crossroads in Berhattan after the naming process." 2300

column3: graphs" "There are n cities and m two-way roads in Berland
column4: each road connecting two distinct cities.Recently the Berland government has made a tough decision to transfer ownership of the roads to private companies. In total
column5: there are 100500 private companies in Berland
column6: numbered by integers from 1 to 100500. After the privatization
column7: every road should belong to exactly one company.The anti-monopoly committee demands that after the privatization each company can own at most two roads. The urbanists of Berland also stated their opinion: each city should be adjacent to the roads owned by at most k companies.Help the government to distribute the roads between the companies so that both conditions are satisfied. That is
column8: each company gets at most two roads
column9: and each city has roads of at most k distinct companies adjacent to it." 2400

column6: inclusive. All file names are unique.The file suggestion feature handles queries

column9: ""hosts""
column10: ""ops""

column3: greedy
column4: implementation" "Polycarp is an introvert person. In fact he is so much of an introvert that he plays ""Monsters and Potions"" board game alone. The board of the game is a row of n cells. The cells are numbered from 1 to n from left to right. There are three types of cells: a cell containing a single monster
column5: a cell containing a single potion or a blank cell (it contains neither a monster nor a potion).Polycarp has m tokens representing heroes fighting monsters
column6: which are initially located in the blank cells s1
column7: s2
column8: \xe2\x80\xa6
column9: sm. Polycarp\'s task is to choose a single cell (rally point) and one by one move all the heroes into this cell. A rally point can be a cell of any of three types.After Policarp selects a rally point
column10: he picks a hero and orders him to move directly to the point. Once that hero reaches the point
column11: Polycarp picks another hero and orders him also to go to the point. And so forth
column12: until all the heroes reach the rally point cell. While going to the point
column13: a hero can not deviate from the direct route or take a step back. A hero just moves cell by cell in the direction of the point until he reaches it. It is possible that multiple heroes are simultaneously in the same cell.Initially the i-th hero has hi hit points (HP). Monsters also have HP
column14: different monsters might have different HP. And potions also have HP
column15: different potions might have different HP.If a hero steps into a cell which is blank (i.e. doesn\'t contain a monster/potion)
column16: hero\'s HP does not change.If a hero steps into a cell containing a monster
column17: then the hero and the monster fight. If monster\'s HP is strictly higher than hero\'s HP
column18: then the monster wins and Polycarp loses the whole game. If hero\'s HP is greater or equal to monster\'s HP
column19: then the hero wins and monster\'s HP is subtracted from hero\'s HP. I.e. the hero survives if his HP drops to zero
column20: but dies (and Polycarp looses) if his HP becomes negative due to a fight. If a hero wins a fight with a monster
column21: then the monster disappears
column22: and the cell becomes blank.If a hero steps into a cell containing a potion
column23: then the hero drinks the potion immediately. As a result
column24: potion\'s HP is added to hero\'s HP
column25: the potion disappears
column26: and the cell becomes blank.Obviously
column27: Polycarp wants to win the game. It means that he must choose such rally point and the order in which heroes move
column28: that every hero reaches the rally point and survives. I.e. Polycarp loses if a hero reaches rally point but is killed by a monster at the same time. Polycarp can use any of n cells as a rally point \xe2\x80\x94 initially it can contain a monster
column29: a potion
column30: or be a blank cell with or without a hero in it.Help Polycarp write a program to choose a rally point and the order in which heroes move." 2300

column1: 1070F Debate greedy "Elections in Berland are coming. There are only two candidates \xe2\x80\x94 Alice and Bob.The main Berland TV channel plans to show political debates. There are n people who want to take part in the debate as a spectator. Each person is described by their influence and political views. There are four kinds of political views:  supporting none of candidates (this kind is denoted as ""00"")
column2: supporting Alice but not Bob (this kind is denoted as ""10"")
column3: supporting Bob but not Alice (this kind is denoted as ""01"")
column4: supporting both candidates (this kind is denoted as ""11""). The direction of the TV channel wants to invite some of these people to the debate. The set of invited spectators should satisfy three conditions:  at least half of spectators support Alice (i.e. 2\xe2\x8b\x85a\xe2\x89\xa5m
column5: where a is number of spectators supporting Alice and m is the total number of spectators)
column6: at least half of spectators support Bob (i.e. 2\xe2\x8b\x85b\xe2\x89\xa5m
column7: where b is number of spectators supporting Bob and m is the total number of spectators)
column8: the total influence of spectators is maximal possible. Help the TV channel direction to select such non-empty set of spectators
column9: or tell that this is impossible." 1500

column2: data structures" "Polycarp has a lot of work to do. Recently he has learned a new time management rule: ""if a task takes five minutes or less
column3: do it immediately"". Polycarp likes the new rule
column4: however he is not sure that five minutes is the optimal value. He supposes that this value d should be chosen based on existing task list.Polycarp has a list of n tasks to complete. The i-th task has difficulty pi
column5: i.e. it requires exactly pi minutes to be done. Polycarp reads the tasks one by one from the first to the n-th. If a task difficulty is d or less
column6: Polycarp starts the work on the task immediately. If a task difficulty is strictly greater than d
column7: he will not do the task at all. It is not allowed to rearrange tasks in the list. Polycarp doesn\'t spend any time for reading a task or skipping it.Polycarp has t minutes in total to complete maximum number of tasks. But he does not want to work all the time. He decides to make a break after each group of m consecutive tasks he was working on. The break should take the same amount of time as it was spent in total on completion of these m tasks.For example
column8: if n=7
column16: d=3 and m=2 Polycarp works by the following schedule:  Polycarp reads the first task
column17: its difficulty is not greater than d (p1=3\xe2\x89\xa4d=3) and works for 3 minutes (i.e. the minutes 1
column19: 3);  Polycarp reads the second task
column20: its difficulty is not greater than d (p2=1\xe2\x89\xa4d=3) and works for 1 minute (i.e. the minute 4);  Polycarp notices that he has finished m=2 tasks and takes a break for 3+1=4 minutes (i.e. on the minutes 5
column23: 8);  Polycarp reads the third task
column24: its difficulty is greater than d (p3=4>d=3) and skips it without spending any time;  Polycarp reads the fourth task
column25: its difficulty is not greater than d (p4=1\xe2\x89\xa4d=3) and works for 1 minute (i.e. the minute 9);  Polycarp reads the tasks 5 and 6
column26: skips both of them (p5>d and p6>d);  Polycarp reads the 7-th task
column27: its difficulty is not greater than d (p7=2\xe2\x89\xa4d=3) and works for 2 minutes (i.e. the minutes 10
column28: 11);  Polycarp notices that he has finished m=2 tasks and takes a break for 1+2=3 minutes (i.e. on the minutes 12
column30: 14). Polycarp stops exactly after t minutes. If Polycarp started a task but has not finished it by that time
column31: the task is not considered as completed. It is allowed to complete less than m tasks in the last group. Also Polycarp considers acceptable to have shorter break than needed after the last group of tasks or even not to have this break at allÂ \xe2\x80\x94 his working day is over and he will have enough time to rest anyway.Please help Polycarp to find such value d
column32: which would allow him to complete maximum possible number of tasks in t minutes." 2100

column1: 1070D "Garbage Disposal" greedy "Enough is enough. Too many times it happened that Vasya forgot to dispose of garbage and his apartment stank afterwards. Now he wants to create a garbage disposal plan and stick to it.For each of next n days Vasya knows ai \xe2\x80\x94 number of units of garbage he will produce on the i-th day. Each unit of garbage must be disposed of either on the day it was produced or on the next day. Vasya disposes of garbage by putting it inside a bag and dropping the bag into a garbage container. Each bag can contain up to k units of garbage. It is allowed to compose and drop multiple bags into a garbage container in a single day.Being economical
column2: Vasya wants to use as few bags as possible. You are to compute the minimum number of bags Vasya needs to dispose of all of his garbage for the given n days. No garbage should be left after the n-th day." 1300

greedy" "Buber is a Berland technology company that specializes in waste of investor\'s money. Recently Buber decided to transfer its infrastructure to a cloud. The company decided to rent CPU cores in the cloud for n consecutive days
column3: which are numbered from 1 to n. Buber requires k CPU cores each day.The cloud provider offers m tariff plans
column4: the i-th tariff plan is characterized by the following parameters:  li and ri \xe2\x80\x94 the i-th tariff plan is available only on days from li to ri
column5: inclusive
column6: ci \xe2\x80\x94 the number of cores per day available for rent on the i-th tariff plan
column7: pi \xe2\x80\x94 the price of renting one core per day on the i-th tariff plan. Buber can arbitrarily share its computing core needs between the tariff plans. Every day Buber can rent an arbitrary number of cores (from 0 to ci) on each of the available plans. The number of rented cores on a tariff plan can vary arbitrarily from day to day.Find the minimum amount of money that Buber will pay for its work for n days from 1 to n. If on a day the total number of cores for all available tariff plans is strictly less than k
column8: then this day Buber will have to work on fewer cores (and it rents all the available cores)
column9: otherwise Buber rents exactly k cores this day." 2000

column2: greedy" "BerkomnadzorÂ \xe2\x80\x94 Federal Service for Supervision of Communications
column3: Information Technology and Mass MediaÂ \xe2\x80\x94 is a Berland federal executive body that protects ordinary residents of Berland from the threats of modern internet.Berkomnadzor maintains a list of prohibited IPv4 subnets (blacklist) and a list of allowed IPv4 subnets (whitelist). All Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in Berland must configure the network equipment to block access to all IPv4 addresses matching the blacklist. Also ISPs must provide access (that is
column4: do not block) to all IPv4 addresses matching the whitelist. If an IPv4 address does not match either of those lists
column5: it\'s up to the ISP to decide whether to block it or not. An IPv4 address matches the blacklist (whitelist) if and only if it matches some subnet from the blacklist (whitelist). An IPv4 address can belong to a whitelist and to a blacklist at the same time
column6: this situation leads to a contradiction (see no solution case in the output description).An IPv4 address is a 32-bit unsigned integer written in the form a.b.c.d
column7: where each of the values a
column8: b
column9: c
column10: d is called an octet and is an integer from 0 to 255 written in decimal notation. For example
column11: IPv4 address 192.168.0.1 can be converted to a 32-bit number using the following expression 192\xe2\x8b\x85224+168\xe2\x8b\x85216+0\xe2\x8b\x8528+1\xe2\x8b\x8520. First octet a encodes the most significant (leftmost) 8 bits
column12: the octets b and cÂ \xe2\x80\x94 the following blocks of 8 bits (in this order)
column13: and the octet d encodes the least significant (rightmost) 8 bits.The IPv4 network in Berland is slightly different from the rest of the world. There are no reserved or internal addresses in Berland and use all 232 possible values.An IPv4 subnet is represented either as a.b.c.d or as a.b.c.d/x (where 0\xe2\x89\xa4x\xe2\x89\xa432). A subnet a.b.c.d contains a single address a.b.c.d. A subnet a.b.c.d/x contains all IPv4 addresses with x leftmost (most significant) bits equal to x leftmost bits of the address a.b.c.d. It is required that 32\xe2\x88\x92x rightmost (least significant) bits of subnet a.b.c.d/x are zeroes.Naturally it happens that all addresses matching subnet a.b.c.d/x form a continuous range. The range starts with address a.b.c.d (its rightmost 32\xe2\x88\x92x bits are zeroes). The range ends with address which x leftmost bits equal to x leftmost bits of address a.b.c.d
column14: and its 32\xe2\x88\x92x rightmost bits are all ones. Subnet contains exactly 232\xe2\x88\x92x addresses. Subnet a.b.c.d/32 contains exactly one address and can also be represented by just a.b.c.d.For example subnet 192.168.0.0/24 contains range of 256 addresses. 192.168.0.0 is the first address of the range
column15: and 192.168.0.255 is the last one.Berkomnadzor\'s engineers have devised a plan to improve performance of Berland\'s global network. Instead of maintaining both whitelist and blacklist they want to build only a single optimised blacklist containing minimal number of subnets. The idea is to block all IPv4 addresses matching the optimised blacklist and allow all the rest addresses. Of course
column16: IPv4 addresses from the old blacklist must remain blocked and all IPv4 addresses from the old whitelist must still be allowed. Those IPv4 addresses which matched neither the old blacklist nor the old whitelist may be either blocked or allowed regardless of their accessibility before. Please write a program which takes blacklist and whitelist as input and produces optimised blacklist. The optimised blacklist must contain the minimal possible number of subnets and satisfy all IPv4 addresses accessibility requirements mentioned above. IPv4 subnets in the source lists may intersect arbitrarily. Please output a single number -1 if some IPv4 address matches both source whitelist and blacklist." 2400
