column4: in other words a rook can go to any cell which shares vertical and to any cell which shares horizontal.Ivan wants his arrangement of rooks to have following properties: For any color there is a rook of this color on a board; For any color the set of rooks of this color is connected; For any two different colors a b union of set of rooks of color a and set of rooks of color b is connected if and only if this two colors harmonize with each other.Please help Ivan find such an arrangement." 1700

column1: 1067C Knights "constructive algorithms" "Ivan places knights on infinite chessboard. Initially there are n knights. column3: shortest paths" "Someone give a strange birthday present to Ivan. It is hedgehogÂ \xe2\x80\x94 connected undirected graph in which one vertex has degree at least 3 (we will call it center) and all other vertices has degree 1. Ivan thought that hedgehog is too boring and decided to make himself k-multihedgehog.Let us define k-multihedgehog as follows: 1-multihedgehog is hedgehog: it has one vertex of degree at least 3 and some vertices of degree 1. Ivan made k-multihedgehog but he is not sure that he did not make any mistakes. That is why he asked you to check if his tree is indeed k-multihedgehog." 1800

column2: implementation" "Maksim has n objects and m boxes
column3: each box has size exactly k. Objects are numbered from 1 to n in order from left to right
column4: the size of the i-th object is ai.Maksim wants to pack his objects into the boxes and he will pack objects by the following algorithm: he takes one of the empty boxes he has
column5: goes from left to right through the objects
column6: and if the i-th object fits in the current box (the remaining size of the box is greater than or equal to ai)
column7: he puts it in the box
column8: and the remaining size of the box decreases by ai. Otherwise he takes the new empty box and continues the process above. If he has no empty boxes and there is at least one object not in some box then Maksim cannot pack the chosen set of objects.Maksim wants to know the maximum number of objects he can pack by the algorithm above. To reach this target
column9: he will throw out the leftmost object from the set until the remaining set of objects can be packed in boxes he has. Your task is to say the maximum number of objects Maksim can pack in boxes he has.Each time when Maksim tries to pack the objects into the boxes
column10: he will make empty all the boxes he has before do it (and the relative order of the remaining set of objects will not change)." 1800

column1: 1066C "Books Queries" implementation "You have got a shelf and want to put some books on it.You are given q queries of three types:  L id \xe2\x80\x94 put a book having index id on the shelf to the left from the leftmost existing book;  R id \xe2\x80\x94 put a book having index id on the shelf to the right from the rightmost existing book;  ? id \xe2\x80\x94 calculate the minimum number of books you need to pop from the left or from the right in such a way that the book with index id will be leftmost or rightmost. You can assume that the first book you will put can have any position (it does not matter) and queries of type 3 are always valid (it is guaranteed that the book in each such query is already placed). You can also assume that you don\'t put the same book on the shelf twice
column2: so ids don\'t repeat in queries of first two types.Your problem is to answer all the queries of type 3 in order they appear in the input.Note that after answering the query of type 3 all the books remain on the shelf and the relative order of books does not change.If you are Python programmer
column3: consider using PyPy instead of Python when you submit your code." 1400

column2: strings" "A non-empty string is called palindrome
column3: if it reads the same from the left to the right and from the right to the left. For example
column4: ""abcba""
column6: and ""abba"" are palindromes
column7: while ""abab"" and ""xy"" are not.A string is called a substring of another string
column8: if it can be obtained from that string by dropping some (possibly zero) number of characters from the beginning and from the end of it. For example
column9: ""abc""
column11: and ""c"" are substrings of the string ""abc""
column12: while ""ac"" and ""d"" are not.Let\'s define a palindromic count of the string as the number of its substrings that are palindromes. For example
column13: the palindromic count of the string ""aaa"" is 6 because all its substrings are palindromes
column14: and the palindromic count of the string ""abc"" is 3 because only its substrings of length 1 are palindromes.You are given a string s. You can arbitrarily rearrange its characters. You goal is to obtain a string with the maximum possible value of palindromic count." 1300

column2: graphs "There are n cities in the country. Two candidates are fighting for the post of the President. The elections are set in the future

column1: 1055G "Jellyfish Nightmare" NA "Bob has put on some weight recently. In order to lose weight a bit
column2: Bob has decided to swim regularly in the pool. However
column3: the day before he went to the pool for the first time he had a weird dream. In this dream Bob was swimming along one of the pool\'s lanes
column4: but also there were some jellyfish swimming around him. It\'s worth mentioning that jellyfish have always been one of Bob\'s deepest childhood fears.Let us assume the following physical model for Bob\'s dream.  The pool\'s lane is an area of the plane between lines x=0 and x=w. Bob is not allowed to swim outside of the lane
column5: but he may touch its bounding lines if he wants.  The jellyfish are very small
column6: but in Bob\'s dream they are extremely swift. Each jellyfish has its area of activity around it. Those areas are circles of various radii
column7: with the jellyfish sitting in their centers. The areas of activity of two jellyfish may overlap and one area of activity may even be fully contained within another one.  Bob has a shape of a convex polygon.  Unfortunately
column8: Bob\'s excess weight has made him very clumsy
column9: and as a result he can\'t rotate his body while swimming. So he swims in a parallel translation pattern. However at any given moment of time he can choose any direction of his movement.  Whenever Bob swims into a jellyfish\'s activity area
column10: it will immediately notice him and sting him very painfully. We assume that Bob has swum into the activity area if at some moment of time the intersection of his body with the jellyfish\'s activity area had a positive area (for example
column11: if they only touch
column12: the jellyfish does not notice Bob).  Once a jellyfish stung Bob
column13: it happily swims away and no longer poses any threat to Bob. Bob wants to swim the lane to its end and get stung the least possible number of times. He will start swimming on the line y=\xe2\x88\x92h
column14: and finish on the line y=h where h=1010." 3500

column2: trees "You are given a connected undirected graph without cycles (that is
column3: a tree) of n vertices

column5: there is a non-negative integer written on every edge.Consider all pairs of vertices (v
column6: u) (that is

column3: strings "Alice has written a program and now tries to improve its readability. One of the ways to improve readability is to give sensible names to the variables

column5: which can replace names of many variable in just one run. To use it
column6: Alice needs to select two strings s and t and after that for each variable the following algorithm is performed: if the variable\'s name contains s as a substring
column7: then the first (and only first) occurrence of s is replaced with t. If the name doesn\'t contain s
column8: then this variable\'s name stays the same.The list of variables is known and for each variable both the initial name and the name Alice wants this variable change to are known. Moreover
column9: for each variable the lengths of the initial name and the target name are equal (otherwise the alignment of the code could become broken). You need to perform renaming of all variables in exactly one run of the massive refactoring command or determine that it is impossible." 2400

column2: number theory" "Bob and Alice are often participating in various programming competitions. Like many competitive programmers

column8: the day is lucky for Alice if it lies in the segment [la+kta;ra+kta] for some non-negative integer k.The Bob\'s lucky day have similar structure

column12: for some non-negative integer k.Alice and Bob want to participate in team competitions together and so they want to find out what is the largest possible number of consecutive days
column13: which are lucky for both Alice and Bob." 1900

column2: math "Ani and Borna are playing a short game on a two-variable polynomial. It\'s a special kind of a polynomial: the monomials are fixed
column3: but all of its coefficients are fill-in-the-blanks dashes
column4: e.g. _xy+_x4y7+_x8y3+\xe2\x80\xa6Borna will fill in the blanks with positive integers. He wants the polynomial to be bounded from below
column5: i.e. his goal is to make sure there exists a real number M such that the value of the polynomial at any point is greater than M.  Ani is mischievous
column6: and wants the polynomial to be unbounded. Along with stealing Borna\'s heart
column7: she can also steal parts of polynomials. Ani is only a petty kind of thief
column8: though: she can only steal at most one monomial from the polynomial before Borna fills in the blanks. If Ani and Borna play their only moves optimally
column9: who wins?" 3400

column2: geometry" "On the surface of a newly discovered planet
column3: which we model by a plane
column4: explorers found remains of two different civilizations in various locations. They would like to learn more about those civilizations and to explore the area they need to build roads between some of locations. But as always
column5: there are some restrictions:   Every two locations of the same civilization are connected by a unique path of roads  No two locations from different civilizations may have road between them (explorers don\'t want to accidentally mix civilizations they are currently exploring)  Roads must be straight line segments  Since intersections are expensive to build
column6: they don\'t want any two roads to intersect (that is
column7: only common point for any two roads may be at some of locations) Obviously all locations are different points in the plane
column8: but explorers found out one more interesting information that may help you \xe2\x80\x93 no three locations lie on the same line!Help explorers and find a solution for their problem
column9: or report it is impossible." 3200

column10: but some planets are more resilient than others. Planets are number 0
column12: \xe2\x80\xa6

column14: the government reinforces or weakens the defenses of a single planet.The government of Bubbledom is interested in the following question: what is the expected number of intergalactic kingdoms Bubbledom will be split into
column15: after a single enemy attack (before they get a chance to rebuild)? In other words
column16: you need to print the expected number of connected components after every attack." 2200

column3: trees" "In an unspecified solar system
column4: there are N planets. A space government company has recently hired space contractors to build M bidirectional Hyperspace\xe2\x84\xa2 highways
column5: each connecting two different planets. The primary objective
column6: which was to make sure that every planet can be reached from any other planet taking only Hyperspace\xe2\x84\xa2 highways
column7: has been completely fulfilled. Unfortunately
column8: lots of space contractors had friends and cousins in the Space Board of Directors of the company
column9: so the company decided to do much more than just connecting all planets. In order to make spending enormous amounts of space money for Hyperspace\xe2\x84\xa2 highways look neccessary
column10: they decided to enforce a strict rule on the Hyperspace\xe2\x84\xa2 highway network: whenever there is a way to travel through some planets and return to the starting point without travelling through any planet twice
column11: every pair of planets on the itinerary should be directly connected by a Hyperspace\xe2\x84\xa2 highway. In other words
column12: the set of planets in every simple cycle induces a complete subgraph.You are designing a Hyperspace\xe2\x84\xa2 navigational app
column13: and the key technical problem you are facing is finding the minimal number of Hyperspace\xe2\x84\xa2 highways one needs to use to travel from planet A to planet B. As this problem is too easy for Bubble Cup
column14: here is a harder task: your program needs to do it for Q pairs of planets." 2300

column1: 1044F DFS "data structures" "Let T be a tree on n vertices. Consider a graph G0

column3: where the i-th update is given as a pair of two distinct integers ui and vi. For every i from 1 to q
column4: we define the graph Gi as follows:   If Gi\xe2\x88\x921 contains an edge {ui
column5: vi}
column6: then remove this edge to form Gi.  Otherwise
column7: add this edge to Gi\xe2\x88\x921 to form Gi.  Formally
column8: Gi:=Gi\xe2\x88\x921\xe2\x96\xb3{{ui
column9: vi}} where \xe2\x96\xb3 denotes the set symmetric difference. Furthermore
column10: it is guaranteed that T is always a subgraph of Gi. In other words
column11: an update never removes an edge of T.Consider a connected graph H and run a depth-first search on it. One can see that the tree edges (i.e. the edges leading to a not yet visited vertex at the time of traversal) form a spanning tree of the graph H. This spanning tree is not generally fixed for a particular graphÂ \xe2\x80\x94 it depends on the starting vertex
column12: and on the order in which the neighbors of each vertex are traversed. We call vertex w good if one can order the neighbors of each vertex in such a way that the depth-first search started from w produces T as the spanning tree. For every i from 1 to q
column13: find and report the number of good vertices." 2700

column5: sortings" "Zibi is a competitive programming coach. There are n competitors who want to be prepared well. The training contests are quite unusualÂ \xe2\x80\x93 there are two people in a team
column6: two problems
column7: and each competitor will code exactly one of them. Of course
column8: people in one team will code different problems.Rules of scoring also aren\'t typical. The first problem is always an implementation problem: you have to implement some well-known algorithm very fast and the time of your typing is rated. The second one is an awful geometry task and you just have to get it accepted in reasonable time. Here the length and difficulty of your code are important. After that
column9: Zibi will give some penalty points (possibly negative) for each solution and the final score of the team is the sum of them (the less the score is
column10: the better).We know that the i-th competitor will always have score xi when he codes the first task and yi when he codes the second task. We can assume
column11: that all competitors know each other\'s skills and during the contest distribute the problems in the way that minimizes their final score. Remember that each person codes exactly one problem in a contest.Zibi wants all competitors to write a contest with each other. However
column12: there are m pairs of people who really don\'t like to cooperate and they definitely won\'t write a contest together. Still
column13: the coach is going to conduct trainings for all possible pairs of people
column14: such that the people in pair don\'t hate each other. The coach is interested for each participant
column15: what will be his or her sum of scores of all teams he trained in?" 1900

column4: r] means that you will move some of them in such a way that their positions will form some segment [x
column5: x+(r\xe2\x88\x92l)].In one step you can move any box to a neighboring cell if it isn\'t occupied by another box (i.e. you can choose i and change ai by 1
column6: all positions should remain distinct). You spend wi units of energy moving the box i by one cell. You can move any box any number of times
column7: in arbitrary order.Sometimes weights of some boxes change
column8: so you have queries of two types:   id nw \xe2\x80\x94 weight wid of the box id becomes nw.  l r \xe2\x80\x94 you should compute the minimum total energy needed to put together boxes with indices in [l
column9: r]. Since the answer can be rather big
column10: print the remainder it gives when divided by 1000000007=109+7. Note that the boxes are not moved during the query
column11: you only should compute the answer. Note that you should minimize the answer
column12: not its remainder modulo 109+7. So if you have two possible answers 2\xe2\x8b\x85109+13 and 2\xe2\x8b\x85109+14
column13: you should choose the first one and print 109+6
column14: even though the remainder of the second answer is 0." 2500

column14: it is guaranteed that for any solution the interactor works non-distinguishable from the situation when the hidden number is fixed beforehand.Hacks are allowed only with fixed hidden number. column3: greedy" "Let\'s consider a simplified version of order book of some stock. The order book is a list of orders (offers) from people that want to buy or sell one unit of the stock
column4: each order is described by direction (BUY or SELL) and price.At every moment of time
column5: every SELL offer has higher price than every BUY offer. In this problem no two ever existed orders will have the same price.The lowest-price SELL order and the highest-price BUY order are called the best offers
column6: marked with black frames on the picture below.  The presented order book says that someone wants to sell the product at price 12 and it\'s the best SELL offer because the other two have higher prices. The best BUY offer has price 10. There are two possible actions in this orderbook:  Somebody adds a new order of some direction with some price. Somebody accepts the best possible SELL or BUY offer (makes a deal). It\'s impossible to accept not the best SELL or BUY offer (to make a deal at worse price). After someone accepts the offer
column7: it is removed from the orderbook forever.It is allowed to add new BUY order only with prices less than the best SELL offer (if you want to buy stock for higher price
column8: then instead of adding an order you should accept the best SELL offer). Similarly
column9: one couldn\'t add a new SELL order with price less or equal to the best BUY offer. For example
column10: you can\'t add a new offer ""SELL 20"" if there is already an offer ""BUY 20"" or ""BUY 25""Â \xe2\x80\x94 in this case you just accept the best BUY offer.You have a damaged order book log (in the beginning the are no orders in book). Every action has one of the two types: ""ADD p"" denotes adding a new order with price p and unknown direction. The order must not contradict with orders still not removed from the order book.  ""ACCEPT p"" denotes accepting an existing best offer with price p and unknown direction.The directions of all actions are lost. Information from the log isn\'t always enough to determine these directions. Count the number of ways to correctly restore all ADD action directions so that all the described conditions are satisfied at any moment. Since the answer could be large
column11: output it modulo 109+7. If it is impossible to correctly restore directions
column12: then output 0." 2100

column4: it constantly runs. If it is in room i in second t then it will run to room ai in second t+1 without visiting any other rooms inbetween (i=ai means that mouse won\'t leave room i). It\'s second 0 in the start. If the mouse is in some room with a mouse trap in it
column5: then the mouse get caught into this trap.That would have been so easy if the girls actually knew where the mouse at. Unfortunately

column7: mouse can be in any room from 1 to n at second 0.What it the minimal total amount of burles girls can spend to set the traps in order to guarantee that the mouse will eventually be caught no matter the room it started from?" 1700

column2: sortings "Panic is rising in the committee for doggo standardizationÂ \xe2\x80\x94 the puppies of the new brood have been born multi-colored! In total there are 26 possible colors of puppies in the nature and they are denoted by letters from \'a\' to \'z\' inclusive.The committee rules strictly prohibit even the smallest diversity between doggos and hence all the puppies should be of the same color. Thus Slava
column3: the committee employee
column4: has been assigned the task to recolor some puppies into other colors in order to eliminate the difference and make all the puppies have one common color.Unfortunately
column5: due to bureaucratic reasons and restricted budget
column6: there\'s only one operation Slava can perform: he can choose a color x such that there are currently at least two puppies of color x and recolor all puppies of the color x into some arbitrary color y. Luckily
column7: this operation can be applied multiple times (including zero).For example
column8: if the number of puppies is 7 and their colors are represented as the string ""abababc""
column9: then in one operation Slava can get the results ""zbzbzbc""
column10: ""bbbbbbc""

column1: 1023C "Bracket Subsequence" greedy "A bracket sequence is a string containing only characters ""("" and "")"". A regular bracket sequence is a bracket sequence that can be transformed into a correct arithmetic expression by inserting characters ""1"" and ""+"" between the original characters of the sequence. For example
column2: bracket sequences ""()()"" and ""(())"" are regular (the resulting expressions are: ""(1)+(1)"" and ""((1+1)+1)"")
column4: ""("" and "")"" are not.Subsequence is a sequence that can be derived from another sequence by deleting some elements without changing the order of the remaining elements.You are given a regular bracket sequence s and an integer number k. Your task is to find a regular bracket sequence of length exactly k such that it is also a subsequence of s.It is guaranteed that such sequence always exists." 1200

column3: math "You received a notebook which is called Death Note. This notebook has infinite number of pages. A rule is written on the last page (huh) of this notebook. It says: ""You have to write names in this notebook during n consecutive days. During the i-th day you have to write exactly ai names."". You got scared (of course you got scared
column4: who wouldn\'t get scared if he just receive a notebook which is named Death Note with a some strange rule written in it?).Of course
column5: you decided to follow this rule. When you calmed down
column6: you came up with a strategy how you will write names in the notebook. You have calculated that each page of the notebook can contain exactly m names. You will start writing names from the first page. You will write names on the current page as long as the limit on the number of names on this page is not exceeded. When the current page is over
column7: you turn the page. Note that you always turn the page when it ends
column8: it doesn\'t matter if it is the last day or not. If after some day the current page still can hold at least one name
column9: during the next day you will continue writing the names from the current page.Now you are interested in the following question: how many times will you turn the page during each day? You are interested in the number of pages you will turn each day from 1 to n." 900

column1: 1015C "Songs Compression" sortings "Ivan has n songs on his phone. The size of the i-th song is ai bytes. Ivan also has a flash drive which can hold at most m bytes in total. Initially
column2: his flash drive is empty.Ivan wants to copy all n songs to the flash drive. He can compress the songs. If he compresses the i-th song
column3: the size of the i-th song reduces from ai to bi bytes (bi<ai).Ivan can compress any subset of the songs (possibly empty) and copy all the songs to his flash drive if the sum of their sizes is at most m. He can compress any subset of the songs (not necessarily contiguous).Ivan wants to find the minimum number of songs he needs to compress in such a way that all his songs fit on the drive (i.e. the sum of their sizes is less than or equal to m).If it is impossible to copy all the songs (even if Ivan compresses all the songs)
column4: print ""-1"". Otherwise print the minimum number of songs Ivan needs to compress." 1100

column2: implementation "Gleb is a famous competitive programming teacher from Innopolis. He is planning a trip to N programming camps in the nearest future. Each camp will be held in a different country. For each of them

column4: the length of the trip in days leni
column5: and the number of days ti this country\'s consulate will take to process a visa application and stick a visa in a passport. Gleb has P (1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89P\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x892) valid passports and is able to decide which visa he wants to put in which passport.For each trip
column6: Gleb will have a flight to that country early in the morning of the day si and will return back late in the evening of the day si\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89leni\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891.To apply for a visa on the day d
column7: Gleb needs to be in Innopolis in the middle of this day. So he can\'t apply for a visa while he is on a trip
column8: including the first and the last days. If a trip starts the next day after the end of the other one
column9: Gleb can\'t apply for a visa between them as well. The earliest Gleb can apply for a visa is day 1.After applying for a visa of country i on day d
column10: Gleb will get his passport back in the middle of the day d\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89ti. Consulates use delivery services
column11: so Gleb can get his passport back even if he is not in Innopolis on this day. Gleb can apply for another visa on the same day he received his passport back
column12: if he is in Innopolis this day. Gleb will not be able to start his trip on day si if he doesn\'t has a passport with a visa for the corresponding country in the morning of day si. In particular
column13: the passport should not be in another country\'s consulate for visa processing.Help Gleb to decide which visas he needs to receive in which passport
column14: and when he should apply for each visa." 3400

column10: the root will remain on the tree. Formally: the tree will have some connected subset of vertices containing the root.After that
column11: the fruits will grow on the tree (only at those vertices which remain). Exactly x fruits will grow in the root. The number of fruits in each remaining vertex will be not less than the sum of the numbers of fruits in the remaining sons of this vertex. It is allowed
column12: that some vertices will not have any fruits.Natasha wondered how many tree configurations can be after the described changes. Since this number can be very large

column14: but there is a vertex in this subset where they have a different amount of fruits." 3400

However
column7: Natasha does not know how much fuel to load into the rocket. Unfortunately
column8: fuel can only be loaded on Earth
column9: so if the rocket runs out of fuel on some other planet
column10: Natasha will not be able to return home. Fuel is needed to take-off from each planet and to land to each planet. It is known that 1 ton of fuel can lift off ai tons of rocket from the i-th planet or to land bi tons of rocket onto the i-th planet. For example

column15: and the amount of initial fuel can be non-integral as well.Help Natasha to calculate the minimum mass of fuel to load into the rocket. Note
column16: that the rocket must spend fuel to carry both useful cargo and the fuel itself. However
column17: it doesn\'t need to carry the fuel which has already been burnt. Assume
column18: that the rocket takes off and lands instantly." 1500

column3: probabilities "Leha is planning his journey from Moscow to Saratov. He hates trains
column4: so he has decided to get from one city to another by car.The path from Moscow to Saratov can be represented as a straight line (well
column5: it\'s not that straight in reality
column6: but in this problem we will consider it to be straight)
column7: and the distance between Moscow and Saratov is n km. Let\'s say that Moscow is situated at the point with coordinate 0 km
column8: and Saratov \xe2\x80\x94 at coordinate n km.Driving for a long time may be really difficult. Formally
column9: if Leha has already covered i kilometers since he stopped to have a rest
column10: he considers the difficulty of covering (i+1)-th kilometer as ai+1. It is guaranteed that for every i\xe2\x88\x88[1
column11: n\xe2\x88\x921] ai\xe2\x89\xa4ai+1. The difficulty of the journey is denoted as the sum of difficulties of each kilometer in the journey.Fortunately
column12: there may be some rest sites between Moscow and Saratov. Every integer point from 1 to n\xe2\x88\x921 may contain a rest site. When Leha enters a rest site
column13: he may have a rest
column14: and the next kilometer will have difficulty a1
column15: the kilometer after it \xe2\x80\x94 difficulty a2
column16: and so on.For example
column17: if n=5 and there is a rest site in coordinate 2
column18: the difficulty of journey will be 2a1+2a2+a3: the first kilometer will have difficulty a1
column19: the second one \xe2\x80\x94 a2
column20: then Leha will have a rest
column21: and the third kilometer will have difficulty a1
column22: the fourth \xe2\x80\x94 a2
column23: and the last one \xe2\x80\x94 a3. Another example: if n=7 and there are rest sites in coordinates 1 and 5
column24: the difficulty of Leha\'s journey is 3a1+2a2+a3+a4.Leha doesn\'t know which integer points contain rest sites. So he has to consider every possible situation. Obviously
column25: there are 2n\xe2\x88\x921 different distributions of rest sites (two distributions are different if there exists some point x such that it contains a rest site in exactly one of these distributions). Leha considers all these distributions to be equiprobable. He wants to calculate p \xe2\x80\x94 the expected value of difficulty of his journey.Obviously
column26: p\xe2\x8b\x852n\xe2\x88\x921 is an integer number. You have to calculate it modulo 998244353." 2000

column6: he leaves the shop.Maxim buys the i-th game if and only if the value of the first bill (which he takes) from his wallet is greater or equal to the cost of the i-th game. If he successfully buys the i-th game
column7: the first bill from his wallet disappears and the next bill becomes first. Otherwise Maxim leaves the first bill in his wallet (this bill still remains the first one) and proceeds to the next game.For example
column8: for array c=[2
column12: 4] and array a=[5
column15: 6] the following process takes place: Maxim buys the first game using the first bill (its value is 5)
column16: the bill disappears
column17: after that the second bill (with value 3) becomes the first one in Maxim\'s wallet
column18: then Maxim doesn\'t buy the second game because c2>a2
column19: the same with the third game
column20: then he buys the fourth game using the bill of value a2 (the third bill becomes the first one in Maxim\'s wallet) and buys the fifth game using the bill of value a3.Your task is to get the number of games Maxim will buy." 800

column3: trees" "In this problem you will have to help Berland army with organizing their command delivery system.There are n officers in Berland army. The first officer is the commander of the army

column5: then we also can say that officer b is a direct subordinate of officer a.Officer x is considered to be a subordinate (direct or indirect) of officer y if one of the following conditions holds:  officer y is the direct superior of officer x;  the direct superior of officer x is a subordinate of officer y. For example
column6: on the picture below the subordinates of the officer 3 are: 5
column10: 9.The structure of Berland army is organized in such a way that every officer
column11: except for the commander
column12: is a subordinate of the commander of the army.Formally
column13: let\'s represent Berland army as a tree consisting of n vertices
column14: in which vertex u corresponds to officer u. The parent of vertex u corresponds to the direct superior of officer u. The root (which has index 1) corresponds to the commander of the army.Berland War Ministry has ordered you to give answers on q queries

column16: ki)
column17: where ui is some officer
column18: and ki is a positive integer.To process the i-th query imagine how a command from ui spreads to the subordinates of ui. Typical DFS (depth first search) algorithm is used here.Suppose the current officer is a and he spreads a command. Officer a chooses b \xe2\x80\x94 one of his direct subordinates (i.e. a child in the tree) who has not received this command yet. If there are many such direct subordinates
column19: then a chooses the one having minimal index. Officer a gives a command to officer b. Afterwards
column20: b uses exactly the same algorithm to spread the command to its subtree. After b finishes spreading the command
column21: officer a chooses the next direct subordinate again (using the same strategy). When officer a cannot choose any direct subordinate who still hasn\'t received this command
column22: officer a finishes spreading the command.Let\'s look at the following example:  If officer 1 spreads a command
column23: officers receive it in the following order: [1
column31: 4].If officer 3 spreads a command
column32: officers receive it in the following order: [3
column38: officers receive it in the following order: [7
column40: officers receive it in the following order: [9].To answer the i-th query (ui
column42: construct a sequence which describes the order in which officers will receive the command if the ui-th officer spreads it. Return the ki-th element of the constructed list or -1 if there are fewer than ki elements in it.You should process queries independently. A query doesn\'t affect the following queries." 1600

column1: 1006D "Two Strings Swaps" implementation "You are given two strings a and b consisting of lowercase English letters
column2: both of length n. The characters of both strings have indices from 1 to n
column3: inclusive. You are allowed to do the following changes:   Choose any index i (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n) and swap characters ai and bi;  Choose any index i (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n) and swap characters ai and an\xe2\x88\x92i+1;  Choose any index i (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n) and swap characters bi and bn\xe2\x88\x92i+1. Note that if n is odd
column4: you are formally allowed to swap a\xe2\x8c\x88n2\xe2\x8c\x89 with a\xe2\x8c\x88n2\xe2\x8c\x89 (and the same with the string b) but this move is useless. Also you can swap two equal characters but this operation is useless as well.You have to make these strings equal by applying any number of changes described above
column5: in any order. But it is obvious that it may be impossible to make two strings equal by these swaps.In one preprocess move you can replace a character in a with another character. In other words
column6: in a single preprocess move you can choose any index i (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4n)
column7: any character c and set ai:=c.Your task is to find the minimum number of preprocess moves to apply in such a way that after them you can make strings a and b equal by applying some number of changes described in the list above.Note that the number of changes you make after the preprocess moves does not matter. Also note that you cannot apply preprocess moves to the string b or make any preprocess moves after the first change is made." 1700

column3: number theory" "Polycarp likes numbers that are divisible by 3.He has a huge number s. Polycarp wants to cut from it the maximum number of numbers that are divisible by 3. To do this
column4: he makes an arbitrary number of vertical cuts between pairs of adjacent digits. As a result
column5: after m such cuts
column6: there will be m+1 parts in total. Polycarp analyzes each of the obtained numbers and finds the number of those that are divisible by 3.For example
column7: if the original number is s=3121
column8: then Polycarp can cut it into three parts with two cuts: 3|1|21. As a result
column9: he will get two numbers that are divisible by 3.Polycarp can make an arbitrary number of vertical cuts
column10: where each cut is made between a pair of adjacent digits. The resulting numbers cannot contain extra leading zeroes (that is
column11: the number can begin with 0 if and only if this number is exactly one character \'0\'). For example
column13: 01 and 00099 are not valid numbers
column14: but 90
column15: 0 and 10001 are valid.What is the maximum number of numbers divisible by 3 that Polycarp can obtain?" 1500

column6: trees" "Sonya likes ice cream very much. She eats it even during programming competitions. That is why the girl decided that she wants to open her own ice cream shops.Sonya lives in a city with n junctions and n\xe2\x88\x921 streets between them. All streets are two-way and connect two junctions. It is possible to travel from any junction to any other using one or more streets. City Hall allows opening shops only on junctions. The girl cannot open shops in the middle of streets. Sonya has exactly k friends whom she can trust. If she opens a shop
column7: one of her friends has to work there and not to allow anybody to eat an ice cream not paying for it. Since Sonya does not want to skip an important competition
column8: she will not work in shops personally.Sonya wants all her ice cream shops to form a simple path of the length r (1\xe2\x89\xa4r\xe2\x89\xa4k)
column9: i.e. to be located in different junctions f1
column10: f2
column11: \xe2\x80\xa6
column12: fr and there is street between fi and fi+1 for each i from 1 to r\xe2\x88\x921.The girl takes care of potential buyers
column13: so she also wants to minimize the maximum distance between the junctions to the nearest ice cream shop. The distance between two junctions a and b is equal to the sum of all the street lengths that you need to pass to get from the junction a to the junction b. So Sonya wants to minimizemaxamin1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4rda
column14: fiwhere a takes a value of all possible n junctions
column15: fiÂ \xe2\x80\x94 the junction where the i-th Sonya\'s shop is located
column16: and dx
column17: yÂ \xe2\x80\x94 the distance between the junctions x and y.Sonya is not sure that she can find the optimal shops locations
column18: that is why she is asking you to help her to open not more than k shops that will form a simple path and the maximum distance between any junction and the nearest shop would be minimal." 2400

column5: while all other cells have the Manhattan distance to the cell containing the zero. The cells with equal numbers have the form of a rhombus
column6: that is why Sonya called this type so.The Manhattan distance between two cells (x1
column7: y1) and (x2
column8: y2) is defined as |x1\xe2\x88\x92x2|+|y1\xe2\x88\x92y2|. For example
column9: the Manhattan distance between the cells (5
column10: 2) and (7
column11: 1) equals to |5\xe2\x88\x927|+|2\xe2\x88\x921|=3.  Example of a rhombic matrix. Note that rhombic matrices are uniquely defined by n

column14: the sequence of n\xe2\x8b\x85m numbers). Note that Sonya will not give you n and m
column15: so only the sequence of numbers in this matrix will be at your disposal.Write a program that finds such an n\xc3\x97m rhombic matrix whose elements are the same as the elements in the sequence in some order." 2300

column2: implementation" "Since Sonya is interested in robotics too
column3: she decided to construct robots that will read and recognize numbers.Sonya has drawn n numbers in a row
column4: ai is located in the i-th position. She also has put a robot at each end of the row (to the left of the first number and to the right of the last number). Sonya will give a number to each robot (they can be either same or different) and run them. When a robot is running
column5: it is moving toward to another robot
column6: reading numbers in the row. When a robot is reading a number that is equal to the number that was given to that robot
column7: it will turn off and stay in the same position.Sonya does not want robots to break
column8: so she will give such numbers that robots will stop before they meet. That is
column9: the girl wants them to stop at different positions so that the first robot is to the left of the second one.For example
column10: if the numbers [1
column14: 3] are written
column15: and Sonya gives the number 1 to the first robot and the number 4 to the second one
column16: the first robot will stop in the 1-st position while the second one in the 3-rd position. In that case
column17: robots will not meet each other. As a result
column18: robots will not be broken. But if Sonya gives the number 4 to the first robot and the number 5 to the second one
column19: they will meet since the first robot will stop in the 3-rd position while the second one is in the 2-nd position.Sonya understands that it does not make sense to give a number that is not written in the row because a robot will not find this number and will meet the other robot.Sonya is now interested in finding the number of different pairs that she can give to robots so that they will not meet. In other words
column20: she wants to know the number of pairs (p
column21: q)
column22: where she will give p to the first robot and q to the second one. Pairs (pi
column23: qi) and (pj
column24: qj) are different if pi\xe2\x89\xa0pj or qi\xe2\x89\xa0qj.Unfortunately
column25: Sonya is busy fixing robots that broke after a failed launch. That is why she is asking you to find the number of pairs that she can give to robots so that they will not meet." 1400

column4: math" "Sonya decided to organize an exhibition of flowers. Since the girl likes only roses and lilies
column5: she decided that only these two kinds of flowers should be in this exhibition.There are n flowers in a row in the exhibition. Sonya can put either a rose or a lily in the i-th position. Thus each of n positions should contain exactly one flower: a rose or a lily.She knows that exactly m people will visit this exhibition. The i-th visitor will visit all flowers from li to ri inclusive. The girl knows that each segment has its own beauty that is equal to the product of the number of roses and the number of lilies.Sonya wants her exhibition to be liked by a lot of people. That is why she wants to put the flowers in such way that the sum of beauties of all segments would be maximum possible." 1300

column1: 1004A "Sonya and Hotels" implementation "Sonya decided that having her own hotel business is the best way of earning money because she can profit and rest wherever she wants.The country where Sonya lives is an endless line. There is a city in each integer coordinate on this line. She has n hotels
column2: where the i-th hotel is located in the city with coordinate xi. Sonya is a smart girl
column3: so she does not open two or more hotels in the same city.Sonya understands that her business needs to be expanded by opening new hotels
column4: so she decides to build one more. She wants to make the minimum distance from this hotel to all others to be equal to d. The girl understands that there are many possible locations to construct such a hotel. Thus she wants to know the number of possible coordinates of the cities where she can build a new hotel. Because Sonya is lounging in a jacuzzi in one of her hotels
column5: she is asking you to find the number of cities where she can build a new hotel so that the minimum distance from the original n hotels to the new one is equal to d." 900

column10: j1\xe2\x88\x92i1] wi1+t=wi2+t. For example
column11: for the text ""to be or not to be"" the segments w[1..2] and w[5..6] are equal
column12: they correspond to the words ""to be"".An abbreviation is a replacement of some segments of words with their first uppercase letters. In order to perform an abbreviation
column13: you have to choose at least two non-intersecting equal segments of words
column14: and replace each chosen segment with the string consisting of first letters of the words in the segment (written in uppercase). For example
column15: for the text ""a ab a a b ab a a b c"" you can replace segments of words w[2..4] and w[6..8] with an abbreviation ""AAA"" and obtain the text ""a AAA b AAA b c""
column16: or you can replace segments of words w[2..5] and w[6..9] with an abbreviation ""AAAB"" and obtain the text ""a AAAB AAAB c"".What is the minimum length of the text after at most one abbreviation?" 2200

column2: graphs" "You are given three integers n
column3: d and k.Your task is to construct an undirected tree on n vertices with diameter d and degree of each vertex at most k
column4: or say that it is impossible.An undirected tree is a connected undirected graph with n\xe2\x88\x921 edges.Diameter of a tree is the maximum length of a simple path (a path in which each vertex appears at most once) between all pairs of vertices of this tree.Degree of a vertex is the number of edges incident to this vertex (i.e. for a vertex u it is the number of edges (u
column5: v) that belong to the tree
column6: where v is any other vertex of a tree)." 2100

column1: 1003D "Coins and Queries" greedy "Polycarp has n coins
column2: the value of the i-th coin is ai. It is guaranteed that all the values are integer powers of 2 (i.e. ai=2d for some non-negative integer number d).Polycarp wants to know answers on q queries. The j-th query is described as integer number bj. The answer to the query is the minimum number of coins that is necessary to obtain the value bj using some subset of coins (Polycarp can use only coins he has). If Polycarp can\'t obtain the value bj
column3: the answer to the j-th query is -1.The queries are independent (the answer on the query doesn\'t affect Polycarp\'s coins)." 1600
math" "The heat during the last few days has been really intense. Scientists from all over the Berland study how the temperatures and weather change
column4: and they claim that this summer is abnormally hot. But any scientific claim sounds a lot more reasonable if there are some numbers involved
column5: so they have decided to actually calculate some value which would represent how high the temperatures are.Mathematicians of Berland State University came up with a special heat intensity value. This value is calculated as follows:Suppose we want to analyze the segment of n consecutive days. We have measured the temperatures during these n days; the temperature during i-th day equals ai.We denote the average temperature of a segment of some consecutive days as the arithmetic mean of the temperature measures during this segment of days. So
column6: if we want to analyze the average temperature from day x to day y
column7: we calculate it as y\xe2\x88\x91i=xaiy\xe2\x88\x92x+1 (note that division is performed without any rounding). The heat intensity value is the maximum of average temperatures over all segments of not less than k consecutive days. For example
column8: if analyzing the measures [3
column11: 2] and k=3
column12: we are interested in segments [3
column17: 2] and [3
column20: 2] (we want to find the maximum value of average temperature over these segments).You have been hired by Berland State University to write a program that would compute the heat intensity value of a given period of days. Are you up to this task?" 1300

column3: trees" "Your friend is developing a computer game. He has already decided how the game world should look like \xe2\x80\x94 it should consist of n locations connected by m two-way passages. column5: then it\'s not fun

column7: requiring the hero to prepare for battle and designing his own tactics of defeating them (commonly these kinds of monsters are called bosses). And your friend wants you to help him place these bosses.The game will start in location s and end in location t
column8: but these locations are not chosen yet. After choosing these locations
column9: your friend will place a boss in each passage such that it is impossible to get from s to t without using this passage. Your friend wants to place as much bosses as possible (because more challenges means more fun
column10: right?)
column11: so he asks you to help him determine the maximum possible number of bosses
column12: considering that any location can be chosen as s or as t." 2100

column2: you bought a brand new smart lamp with programming features. At first

column7: preinstalled program is a good program.The lamp follows program a in next manner: at moment 0 turns power and light on. Then at moment ai the lamp flips its state to opposite (if it was lit
column8: it turns off
column9: and vice versa). The state of the lamp flips instantly: for example
column10: if you turn the light off at moment 1 and then do nothing
column11: the total time when the lamp is lit will be 1. Finally
column12: at moment M the lamp is turning its power off regardless of its state.Since you are not among those people who read instructions
column13: and you don\'t understand the language it\'s written in
column14: you realize (after some testing) the only possible way to alter the preinstalled program. You can insert at most one element into the program a

column17: then its lit for y\xe2\x88\x92x units of time. Segments of time when the lamp is lit are summed up." 1500

column3: graphs" "You are given an undirected graph consisting of n vertices and m edges. Your task is to find the number of connected components which are cycles.Here are some definitions of graph theory.An undirected graph consists of two sets: set of nodes (called vertices) and set of edges. Each edge connects a pair of vertices. All edges are bidirectional (i.e. if a vertex a is connected with a vertex b
column4: a vertex b is also connected with a vertex a). An edge can\'t connect vertex with itself
column5: there is at most one edge between a pair of vertices.Two vertices u and v belong to the same connected component if and only if there is at least one path along edges connecting u and v.A connected component is a cycle if and only if its vertices can be reordered in such a way that:  the first vertex is connected with the second vertex by an edge
column6: the second vertex is connected with the third vertex by an edge
column7: ...  the last vertex is connected with the first vertex by an edge
column8: all the described edges of a cycle are distinct. A cycle doesn\'t contain any other edges except described above. By definition any cycle contains three or more vertices.  There are 6 connected components
column9: 2 of them are cycles: [7

column1: 959C "Mahmoud and Ehab and the wrong algorithm" "constructive algorithms
column2: trees" "Mahmoud was trying to solve the vertex cover problem on trees. The problem statement is:Given an undirected tree consisting of n nodes

column5: \xe2\x80\x89v) that belongs to the tree
column6: either u is in the set
column7: or v is in the set
column8: or both are in the set. Mahmoud has found the following algorithm:  Root the tree at node 1.  Count the number of nodes at an even depth. Let it be evenCnt.  Count the number of nodes at an odd depth. Let it be oddCnt.  The answer is the minimum between evenCnt and oddCnt. The depth of a node in a tree is the number of edges in the shortest path between this node and the root. The depth of the root is 0.Ehab told Mahmoud that this algorithm is wrong
column9: but he didn\'t believe because he had tested his algorithm against many trees and it worked
column10: so Ehab asked you to find 2 trees consisting of n nodes. The algorithm should find an incorrect answer for the first tree and a correct answer for the second one." 1500

column2: dp" "Heidi is now just one code away from breaking the encryption of the Death Star plans. The screen that should be presenting her with the description of the next code looks almost like the previous one
column3: though who would have thought that the evil Empire engineers would fill this small screen with several million digits! It is just ridiculous to think that anyone would read them all...Heidi is once again given a sequence A and two integers k and p. She needs to find out what the encryption key S is.Let X be a sequence of integers
column4: and p a positive integer. We define the score of X to be the sum of the elements of X modulo p.Heidi is given a sequence A that consists of N integers
column5: and also given integers k and p. Her goal is to split A into k parts such that:   Each part contains at least 1 element of A
column6: and each part consists of contiguous elements of A.  No two parts overlap.  The total sum S of the scores of those parts is minimized (not maximized!). Output the sum S
column7: which is the encryption code." 2500

column6: and each part consists of contiguous elements of A.  No two parts overlap.  The total sum S of the scores of those parts is maximized. Output the sum S \xe2\x80\x93 the encryption code." 2000

column1: 958C1 "Encryption (easy)" "brute force" "Rebel spy Heidi has just obtained the plans for the Death Star from the Empire and

column6: which is defined as follows:Define the score of X to be the sum of the elements of X modulo p.Heidi is given a sequence A that consists of N integers
column7: and also given an integer p. She needs to split A into 2 parts such that:   Each part contains at least 1 element of A
column8: and each part consists of contiguous elements of A.  The two parts do not overlap.  The total sum S of the scores of those two parts is maximized. This is the encryption code. Output the sum S
column9: which is the encryption code." 1200

column2: trees "You\'re given a tree with n vertices rooted at 1.We say that there\'s a k-ary heap of depth m located at u if the following holds:  For m\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x891 u itself is a k-ary heap of depth 1.  For m\xe2\x80\x89>\xe2\x80\x891 vertex u is a k-ary heap of depth m if at least k of its children are k-ary heaps of depth at least m\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891. Denote dpk(u) as maximum depth of k-ary heap in the subtree of u (including u). Your goal is to compute ." 2600

column1: 955E Icicles NA "Andrew\'s favourite Krakozyabra has recenly fled away and now he\'s eager to bring it back!At the moment the refugee is inside an icy cave with n icicles dangling from the ceiling located in integer coordinates numbered from 1 to n. The distance between floor and the i-th icicle is equal to ai.Andrew is free to choose an arbitrary integer point T in range from 1 to n inclusive and at time instant 0 launch a sound wave spreading into both sides (left and right) at the speed of one point per second. Any icicle touched by the wave starts falling at the same speed (that means that in a second the distance from floor to icicle decreases by one but cannot become less that zero). While distance from icicle to floor is more than zero
column2: it is considered passable; as soon as it becomes zero
column3: the icicle blocks the path and prohibits passing.Krakozyabra is initially (i.e. at time instant 0) is located at point  and starts running in the right direction at the speed of one point per second. You can assume that events in a single second happen in the following order: first Krakozyabra changes its position
column4: and only then the sound spreads and icicles fall; in particular
column5: that means that if Krakozyabra is currently at point  and the falling (i.e. already touched by the sound wave) icicle at point i is 1 point from the floor
column6: then Krakozyabra will pass it and find itself at  and only after that the icicle will finally fall and block the path.Krakozyabra is considered entrapped if there are fallen (i.e. with ai\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890) icicles both to the left and to the right of its current position. Help Andrew find the minimum possible time it takes to entrap Krakozyabra by choosing the optimal value of T or report that this mission is impossible." 2900

column2: strings" "Jenya has recently acquired quite a useful tool \xe2\x80\x94 k-scissors for cutting strings. For example

column4: but not ab and bc since they\'re intersecting.It\'s a nice idea to test this tool before using it in practice. After looking through the papers
column5: Jenya came up with two strings s and t. His question is whether it is possible to apply his scissors to string s such that the resulting concatenation contains t as a substring?" 2600

column3: Andrew realised that he had forgotten to feed his only cat for yet another time (guess why there\'s only one cat). The cat\'s current hunger level is H points
column4: moreover each minute without food increases his hunger by D points.At any time Andrew can visit the store where tasty buns are sold (you can assume that is doesn\'t take time to get to the store and back). One such bun costs C roubles and decreases hunger by N points. Since the demand for bakery drops heavily in the evening
column5: there is a special 20% discount for buns starting from 20:00 (note that the cost might become rational). Of course
column6: buns cannot be sold by parts.Determine the minimum amount of money Andrew has to spend in order to feed his cat. The cat is considered fed if its hunger level is less than or equal to zero." 1100

column2: math "Suppose you have two strings s and t
column3: and their length is equal. You may perform the following operation any number of times: choose two different characters c1 and c2
column4: and replace every occurence of c1 in both strings with c2. Let\'s denote the distance between strings s and t as the minimum number of operations required to make these strings equal. For example
column5: if s is abcd and t is ddcb
column6: the distance between them is 2 \xe2\x80\x94 we may replace every occurence of a with b
column7: so s becomes bbcd
column8: and then we may replace every occurence of b with d
column9: so both strings become ddcd.You are given two strings S and T. For every substring of S consisting of |T| characters you have to determine the distance between this substring and T." 2200

column2: dp "You are given a rooted tree. Let\'s denote d(x) as depth of node x: depth of the root is 1
column3: depth of any other node x is d(y)\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891
column4: where y is a parent of x.The tree has the following property: every node x with d(x)\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89i has exactly ai children. Maximum possible depth of a node is n
column5: and an\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890.We define fk as the number of unordered pairs of vertices in the tree such that the number of edges on the simple path between them is equal to k.Calculate fk modulo 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897 for every 1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89k\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x892n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x892." 2500

Three sides of the castle are protected by impassable mountains and the remaining side is occupied by a long wall that is split into n sections. At this moment there are exactly ai archers located at the i-th section of this wall. You know that archer who stands at section i can shoot orcs that attack section located at distance not exceeding r
column5: that is all such sections j that |i\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89j|\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89r. In particular
column6: r\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x890 means that archers are only capable of shooting at orcs who attack section i.Denote as defense level of section i the total number of archers who can shoot at the orcs attacking this section. Reliability of the defense plan is the minimum value of defense level of individual wall section.There is a little time left till the attack so you can\'t redistribute archers that are already located at the wall. However
column7: there is a reserve of k archers that you can distribute among wall sections in arbitrary way. You would like to achieve maximum possible reliability of the defence plan." 2000

column7: such that if the new road between these two junctions is built the distance between s and t won\'t decrease." 1600

column1: 954A "Diagonal Walking" implementation "Mikhail walks on a 2D plane. He can go either up or right. You are given a sequence of Mikhail\'s moves. He thinks that this sequence is too long and he wants to make it as short as possible.In the given sequence moving up is described by character U and moving right is described by character R. Mikhail can replace any pair of consecutive moves RU or UR with a diagonal move (described as character D). After that
column2: he can go on and do some other replacements
column3: until there is no pair of consecutive moves RU or UR left.Your problem is to print the minimum possible length of the sequence of moves after the replacements." 800

column1: 952G "Puzzling Language" "constructive algorithms" "In this problem you will write a simple code generator for a 2D programming language derived from Brainfuck.The code in this language is a rectangular grid of characters \'.\' and \'X\'. The code is converted to a Brainfuck program as follows: the characters are read in the usual order (top to bottom
column3: and each \'X\' character is converted a Brainfuck instruction to be executed. The instruction is defined by the left
column4: top and right neighbors of the \'X\' character using the following conversion table:  You are given a string. Output a program in the described language which prints this string.You can download the language interpreter used for judging here: https://assets.codeforces.com/rounds/952/puzzling-interpreter.cpp (use C++11 to compile the code). Note several implementation details: The first step of the language interpretation is conversion to a Brainfuck program
column5: which is then executed. The code must be rectangular
column6: with all lines of the same length. It can have at most 10
column7: 000 lines and 10
column8: 000 columns
column9: and can have at most 500
column10: 000 \'X\' characters. The code has toroidal topology
column11: i.e. the \'X\' on the first line will have top neighbor in the last line. Brainfuck interpreter has 30000 memory cells which store integers from 0 to 255 with increment/decrement done modulo 256. Console input (
column12: command) is allowed in Brainfuck code but has no effect when executed." 2200

column1: 952E "Cheese Board" NA "Not to be confused with chessboard." 2000
952D "I\'m Feeling Lucky!" probabilities "You have one chip and one chance to play roulette. Are you feeling lucky?" 1800
952C "Ravioli Sort" implementation "Everybody knows of spaghetti sort. You decided to implement an analog sorting algorithm yourself
column2: but as you survey your pantry you realize you\'re out of spaghetti! The only type of pasta you have is ravioli
column3: but you are not going to let this stop you...You come up with the following algorithm. For each number in the array ai
column4: build a stack of ai ravioli. The image shows the stack for ai\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x894.  Arrange the stacks in one row in the order in which the corresponding numbers appear in the input array. Find the tallest one (if there are several stacks of maximal height
column5: use the leftmost one). Remove it and add its height to the end of the output array. Shift the stacks in the row so that there is no gap between them. Repeat the procedure until all stacks have been removed.At first you are very happy with your algorithm
column6: but as you try it on more inputs you realize that it doesn\'t always produce the right sorted array. Turns out when two stacks of ravioli are next to each other (at any step of the process) and differ in height by two or more
column7: the top ravioli of the taller stack slides down on top of the lower stack.Given an input array
column8: figure out whether the described algorithm will sort it correctly." 1600

column1: 949E "Binary Cards" "brute force" "It is never too late to play the fancy ""Binary Cards"" game!There is an infinite amount of cards of positive and negative ranks that are used in the game. The absolute value of any card rank is a power of two
column2: i.e. each card has a rank of either 2k or \xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x892k for some integer k\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa5\xe2\x80\x890. There is an infinite amount of cards of any valid rank.At the beginning of the game player forms his deck that is some multiset (possibly empty) of cards. It is allowed to pick any number of cards of any rank but the small deck is considered to be a skill indicator. Game consists of n rounds. In the i-th round jury tells the player an integer ai. After that the player is obligated to draw such a subset of his deck that the sum of ranks of the chosen cards is equal to ai (it is allowed to not draw any cards
column3: in which case the sum is considered to be equal to zero). If player fails to do so
column4: he loses and the game is over. Otherwise
column5: player takes back all of his cards into his deck and the game proceeds to the next round. Player is considered a winner if he is able to draw the suitable set of cards in each of the rounds.Somebody told you which numbers ai the jury is going to tell you in each round. Now you want to pick a deck consisting of the minimum number of cards that allows you to win the ""Binary Cards"" game." 2700

column4: sortings" "Instructors of Some Informatics School make students go to bed.The house contains n rooms
column5: in each room exactly b students were supposed to sleep. However
column6: at the time of curfew it happened that many students are not located in their assigned rooms. The rooms are arranged in a row and numbered from 1 to n. Initially
column7: in i-th room there are ai students. All students are currently somewhere in the house
column8: therefore a1\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89a2\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89...\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x89an\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89nb. Also 2 instructors live in this house.The process of curfew enforcement is the following. One instructor starts near room 1 and moves toward room n
column9: while the second instructor starts near room n and moves toward room 1. After processing current room
column10: each instructor moves on to the next one. Both instructors enter rooms and move simultaneously
column11: if n is odd
column12: then only the first instructor processes the middle room. When all rooms are processed
column13: the process ends.When an instructor processes a room
column14: she counts the number of students in the room
column15: then turns off the light
column16: and locks the room. Also
column17: if the number of students inside the processed room is not equal to b
column18: the instructor writes down the number of this room into her notebook (and turns off the light
column19: and locks the room). Instructors are in a hurry (to prepare the study plan for the next day)
column20: so they don\'t care about who is in the room
column21: but only about the number of students.While instructors are inside the rooms
column22: students can run between rooms that are not locked and not being processed. A student can run by at most d rooms
column23: that is she can move to a room with number that differs my at most d. Also
column24: after (or instead of) running each student can hide under a bed in a room she is in. In this case the instructor will not count her during the processing. In each room any number of students can hide simultaneously.Formally
column25: here is what\'s happening:  A curfew is announced
column26: at this point in room i there are ai students.  Each student can run to another room but not further than d rooms away from her initial room
column27: or stay in place. After that each student can optionally hide under a bed.  Instructors enter room 1 and room n
column28: they count students there and lock the room (after it no one can enter or leave this room).  Each student from rooms with numbers from 2 to n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891 can run to another room but not further than d rooms away from her current room
column29: or stay in place. Each student can optionally hide under a bed.  Instructors move from room 1 to room 2 and from room n to room n\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891.  This process continues until all rooms are processed. Let x1 denote the number of rooms in which the first instructor counted the number of non-hidden students different from b
column30: and x2 be the same number for the second instructor. Students know that the principal will only listen to one complaint
column31: therefore they want to minimize the maximum of numbers xi. Help them find this value if they use the optimal strategy." 2300

column2: graphs" "BigData Inc. is a corporation that has n data centers indexed from 1 to n that are located all over the world. These data centers provide storage for client data (you can figure out that client data is really big!).Main feature of services offered by BigData Inc. is the access availability guarantee even under the circumstances of any data center having an outage. Such a guarantee is ensured by using the two-way replication. Two-way replication is such an approach for data storage that any piece of data is represented by two identical copies that are stored in two different data centers.For each of m company clients
column3: let us denote indices of two different data centers storing this client data as ci
column4: \xe2\x80\x891 and ci
column5: \xe2\x80\x892.In order to keep data centers operational and safe
column6: the software running on data center computers is being updated regularly. Release cycle of BigData Inc. is one day meaning that the new version of software is being deployed to the data center computers each day.Data center software update is a non-trivial long process
column7: that is why there is a special hour-long time frame that is dedicated for data center maintenance. During the maintenance period
column8: data center computers are installing software updates
column9: and thus they may be unavailable. Consider the day to be exactly h hours long. For each data center there is an integer uj (0\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89uj\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89h\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891) defining the index of an hour of day
column10: such that during this hour data center j is unavailable due to maintenance.Summing up everything above
column11: the condition uci
column13: \xe2\x80\x892 should hold for each client
column14: or otherwise his data may be unaccessible while data centers that store it are under maintenance.Due to occasional timezone change in different cities all over the world
column15: the maintenance time in some of the data centers may change by one hour sometimes. Company should be prepared for such situation
column16: that is why they decided to conduct an experiment
column17: choosing some non-empty subset of data centers
column18: and shifting the maintenance time for them by an hour later (i.e. if uj\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89h\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891
column19: then the new maintenance hour would become 0
column20: otherwise it would become uj\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891). Nonetheless
column21: such an experiment should not break the accessibility guarantees
column22: meaning that data of any client should be still available during any hour of a day after the data center maintenance times are changed.Such an experiment would provide useful insights
column23: but changing update time is quite an expensive procedure
column24: that is why the company asked you to find out the minimum number of data centers that have to be included in an experiment in order to keep the data accessibility guarantees." 1900
