column2: constructive algorithms" "For a permutation P[1... N] of integers from 1 to N
column3: function f is defined as follows:  Let g(i) be the minimum positive integer j such that f(i
column4: \xe2\x80\x89j)\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89i. We can show such j always exists.For given N
column7: find a permutation P of integers from 1 to N such that for 1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89i\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89N
column8: g(i) equals either A or B." 1600

column3: dfs and similar" "Let us define two functions f and g on positive integer numbers.   You need to process Q queries. In each query
column4: you will be given three integers l
column5: r and k. You need to print the number of integers x between l and r inclusive
column6: such that g(x)\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89k." 1300

column1: 932A "Palindromic Supersequence" "constructive algorithms" "You are given a string A. Find a string B
column2: where B is a palindrome and A is a subsequence of B.A subsequence of a string is a string that can be derived from it by deleting some (not necessarily consecutive) characters without changing the order of the remaining characters. For example
column3: ""cotst"" is a subsequence of ""contest"".A palindrome is a string that reads the same forward or backward.The length of string B should be at most 104. It is guaranteed that there always exists such string.You do not need to find the shortest answer
column4: the only restriction is that the length of string B should not exceed 104." 800

column2: math "Anya and Kirill are doing a physics laboratory work. In one of the tasks they have to measure some value n times
column3: and then compute the average value to lower the error.Kirill has already made his measurements
column4: and has got the following integer values: x1
column5: x2
column7: xn. It is important that the values are close to each other
column8: namely
column9: the difference between the maximum value and the minimum value is at most 2.Anya does not want to make the measurements
column10: however
column11: she can\'t just copy the values from Kirill\'s work
column12: because the error of each measurement is a random value
column13: and this coincidence will be noted by the teacher. Anya wants to write such integer values y1
column14: y2
column16: yn in her work
column17: that the following conditions are met:  the average value of x1
column20: \xe2\x80\x89xn is equal to the average value of y1
column23: \xe2\x80\x89yn; all Anya\'s measurements are in the same bounds as all Kirill\'s measurements
column24: that is
column25: the maximum value among Anya\'s values is not greater than the maximum value among Kirill\'s values
column26: and the minimum value among Anya\'s values is not less than the minimum value among Kirill\'s values; the number of equal measurements in Anya\'s work and Kirill\'s work is as small as possible among options with the previous conditions met. Formally
column27: the teacher goes through all Anya\'s values one by one
column28: if there is equal value in Kirill\'s work and it is not strike off yet
column29: he strikes off this Anya\'s value and one of equal values in Kirill\'s work. The number of equal measurements is then the total number of strike off values in Anya\'s work. Help Anya to write such a set of measurements that the conditions above are met." 1700

column2: implementation" "The last stage of Football World Cup is played using the play-off system.There are n teams left in this stage
column3: they are enumerated from 1 to n. Several rounds are held
column4: in each round the remaining teams are sorted in the order of their ids
column5: then the first in this order plays with the second
column6: the thirdÂ \xe2\x80\x94 with the fourth
column7: the fifthÂ \xe2\x80\x94 with the sixth
column8: and so on. It is guaranteed that in each round there is even number of teams. The winner of each game advances to the next round
column9: the loser is eliminated from the tournament
column10: there are no draws. In the last round there is the only game with two remaining teams: the round is called the Final
column11: the winner is called the champion
column12: and the tournament is over.Arkady wants his two favorite teams to play in the Final. Unfortunately
column13: the team ids are already determined
column14: and it may happen that it is impossible for teams to meet in the Final
column15: because they are to meet in some earlier stage
column16: if they are strong enough. Determine
column17: in which round the teams with ids a and b can meet." 1200

column3: implementation
column4: math" "Two friends are on the coordinate axis Ox in points with integer coordinates. One of them is in the point x1\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89a
column5: another one is in the point x2\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89b. Each of the friends can move by one along the line in any direction unlimited number of times. When a friend moves
column6: the tiredness of a friend changes according to the following rules: the first move increases the tiredness by 1
column7: the second move increases the tiredness by 2
column8: the thirdÂ \xe2\x80\x94 by 3 and so on. For example
column9: if a friend moves first to the left
column10: then to the right (returning to the same point)
column11: and then again to the left his tiredness becomes equal to 1\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x892\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x893\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x896.The friends want to meet in a integer point. Determine the minimum total tiredness they should gain
column12: if they meet in the same point." 800

column3: math" "Arkady and Kirill visited an exhibition of rare coins. The coins were located in a row and enumerated from left to right from 1 to k
column4: each coin either was laid with its obverse (front) side up
column5: or with its reverse (back) side up.Arkady and Kirill made some photos of the coins
column6: each photo contained a segment of neighboring coins. Akrady is interested in obverses
column7: so on each photo made by him there is at least one coin with obverse side up. On the contrary
column8: Kirill is interested in reverses
column9: so on each photo made by him there is at least one coin with its reverse side up.The photos are lost now
column10: but Arkady and Kirill still remember the bounds of the segments of coins each photo contained. Given this information
column11: compute the remainder of division by 109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897 of the number of ways to choose the upper side of each coin in such a way
column12: that on each Arkady\'s photo there is at least one coin with obverse side up
column13: and on each Kirill\'s photo there is at least one coin with reverse side up." 2900

column3: implementation" "Consider the following game for two players. There is one white token and some number of black tokens. Each token is placed on a plane in a point with integer coordinates x and y.The players take turn making moves
column4: white starts. On each turn
column5: a player moves all tokens of their color by 1 to up
column6: down
column7: left or right. Black player can choose directions for each token independently.After a turn of the white player the white token can not be in a point where a black token is located. There are no other constraints on locations of the tokens: positions of black tokens can coincide
column8: after a turn of the black player and initially the white token can be in the same point with some black point. If at some moment the white player can\'t make a move
column9: he loses. If the white player makes 10100500 moves
column10: he wins.You are to solve the following problem. You are given initial positions of all black tokens. It is guaranteed that initially all these positions are distinct. In how many places can the white token be located initially so that if both players play optimally
column11: the black player wins?" 2500

column2: dp" "Young Teodor enjoys drawing. His favourite hobby is drawing segments with integer borders inside his huge [1;m] segment. One day Teodor noticed that picture he just drawn has one interesting feature: there doesn\'t exist an integer point
column3: that belongs each of segments in the picture. Having discovered this fact
column4: Teodor decided to share it with Sasha.Sasha knows that Teodor likes to show off so he never trusts him. Teodor wants to prove that he can be trusted sometimes
column5: so he decided to convince Sasha that there is no such integer point in his picture
column6: which belongs to each segment. However Teodor is lazy person and neither wills to tell Sasha all coordinates of segments\' ends nor wills to tell him their amount
column7: so he suggested Sasha to ask him series of questions \'Given the integer point xi
column8: how many segments in Fedya\'s picture contain that point?\'
column9: promising to tell correct answers for this questions.Both boys are very busy studying and don\'t have much time
column10: so they ask you to find out how many questions can Sasha ask Teodor
column11: that having only answers on his questions
column12: Sasha can\'t be sure that Teodor isn\'t lying to him. Note that Sasha doesn\'t know amount of segments in Teodor\'s picture. Sure
column13: Sasha is smart person and never asks about same point twice." 1900

column3: strings "Vasya and Kolya play a game with a string
column4: using the following rules. Initially
column5: Kolya creates a string s
column6: consisting of small English letters
column7: and uniformly at random chooses an integer k from a segment [0
column8: \xe2\x80\x89len(s)\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891]. He tells Vasya this string s
column9: and then shifts it k letters to the left
column10: i.Â e. creates a new string t\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89sk\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891sk\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x892... sns1s2... sk. Vasya does not know the integer k nor the string t
column11: but he wants to guess the integer k. To do this
column12: he asks Kolya to tell him the first letter of the new string
column13: and then
column14: after he sees it
column15: open one more letter on some position
column16: which Vasya can choose.Vasya understands
column17: that he can\'t guarantee that he will win
column18: but he wants to know the probability of winning
column19: if he plays optimally. He wants you to compute this probability. Note that Vasya wants to know the value of k uniquely
column20: it means
column21: that if there are at least two cyclic shifts of s that fit the information Vasya knowns
column22: Vasya loses. Of course
column23: at any moment of the game Vasya wants to maximize the probability of his win." 1600

column3: trees" "In Arcady\'s garden there grows a peculiar apple-tree that fruits one time per year. Its peculiarity can be explained in following way: there are n inflorescences
column4: numbered from 1 to n. Inflorescence number 1 is situated near base of tree and any other inflorescence with number i (i\xe2\x80\x89>\xe2\x80\x891) is situated at the top of branch
column5: which bottom is pi-th inflorescence and pi\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x89i.Once tree starts fruiting
column6: there appears exactly one apple in each inflorescence. The same moment as apples appear
column7: they start to roll down along branches to the very base of tree. Each second all apples
column8: except ones in first inflorescence simultaneously roll down one branch closer to tree base
column9: e.g. apple in a-th inflorescence gets to pa-th inflorescence. Apples that end up in first inflorescence are gathered by Arcady in exactly the same moment. Second peculiarity of this tree is that once two apples are in same inflorescence they annihilate. This happens with each pair of apples
column10: e.g. if there are 5 apples in same inflorescence in same time
column11: only one will not be annihilated and if there are 8 apples
column12: all apples will be annihilated. Thus
column13: there can be no more than one apple in each inflorescence in each moment of time.Help Arcady with counting number of apples he will be able to collect from first inflorescence during one harvest." 1500

column3: trees" "Arcady is a copywriter. His today\'s task is to type up an already well-designed story using his favorite text editor.Arcady types words
column4: punctuation signs and spaces one after another. Each letter and each sign (including line feed) requires one keyboard click in order to be printed. Moreover
column5: when Arcady has a non-empty prefix of some word on the screen
column6: the editor proposes a possible autocompletion for this word
column7: more precisely one of the already printed words such that its prefix matches the currently printed prefix if this word is unique. For example
column8: if Arcady has already printed \xc2\xabcodeforces\xc2\xbb
column9: \xc2\xabcoding\xc2\xbb and \xc2\xabcodeforces\xc2\xbb once again
column10: then there will be no autocompletion attempt for \xc2\xabcod\xc2\xbb
column11: but if he proceeds with \xc2\xabcode\xc2\xbb
column12: the editor will propose \xc2\xabcodeforces\xc2\xbb.With a single click Arcady can follow the editor\'s proposal
column13: i.e. to transform the current prefix to it. Note that no additional symbols are printed after the autocompletion (no spaces
column14: line feeds

column3: implementation" "Polycarp is currently developing a project in Vaja language and using a popular dependency management system called Vamen. From Vamen\'s point of view both Vaja project and libraries are treated projects for simplicity.A project in Vaja has its own uniqie non-empty name consisting of lowercase latin letters with length not exceeding 10 and version \xe2\x80\x94 positive integer from 1 to 106. Each project (keep in mind that it is determined by both its name and version) might depend on other projects. For sure
column4: there are no cyclic dependencies.You\'re given a list of project descriptions. The first of the given projects is the one being developed by Polycarp at this moment. Help Polycarp determine all projects that his project depends on (directly or via a certain chain). It\'s possible that Polycarp\'s project depends on two different versions of some project. In this case collision resolving is applied
column5: i.e. for each such project the system chooses the version that minimizes the distance from it to Polycarp\'s project. If there are several options
column6: the newer (with the maximum version) is preferred. This version is considered actual; other versions and their dependencies are ignored.More formal
column7: choose such a set of projects of minimum possible size that the following conditions hold:   Polycarp\'s project is chosen;  Polycarp\'s project depends (directly or indirectly) on all other projects in the set;  no two projects share the name;  for each project x that some other project in the set depends on we have either x or some y with other version and shorter chain to Polycarp\'s project chosen. In case of ties the newer one is chosen. Output all Polycarp\'s project\'s dependencies (Polycarp\'s project itself should\'t be printed) in lexicographical order." 1900
